Op. 443; ἀμπελίδος ὄρχον ἐ. to draw a line of vines, i.e. plant them in line, Ar. Ach. 995: generally, plant, produce, ἐλᾷ τέσσαρας ἀρετὰς αἰών Pi. N. 3.74.
κολῳὸν ἐλαύνειν prolong, keep up the brawl, Il. 1.575.
ἐξ ὄσσων ἐς γαῖαν ἐ. δάκρυ E. Supp. 96.

data.quote: ἐξ ὄσσων ἐς γαῖαν ἐ. δάκρυ

children.definition: of a stag or hart, κέρας hartshorn, Arist. HA 534b23; ἐ. κρέα venison, X. An. 1.5.2, PSI 6.594.15 (iii A.D.).

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐ. δίκτυα for catching stags, Aen.Tact. 11.6, 38.7.
deer-like, cowardly, EM 326.10.
ἐλάφειον, τό, = ὠκιμοειδές, Ps.- Dsc. 4.28.
deerskin, Poll. 7.90.
shooting of deer, Call. Dian. 262: in pl., S. Aj. 178 (lyr.).
festival of Artemis, IG 9(1).90 ( Phocis), Plu. QConv. 2.660d.

definition: Ἐλαφηβολιών, ῶνος, ὁ (sc. μήν), the ninth month of the Attic year, in which

children.definition: the Elaphebolia were held, Foed. ap. Th. 4.118, etc.; also at Iasos, CIG 2675; at Apollonia in Chalcidice, Hegesand. 40.
shooting deer, Il. 18.319; of Artemis, h.Hom. 27.2, Anacr. 1.1: Dor. ἐλαφᾱβ- S. Tr. 213 (lyr.).

definition: ἐλαφίαι οἱ τῶν ἐλάφων ἀστράγαλοι, Hsch.

children.definition: young deer, fawn, Aq. 1 Ki. 24.3, Hsch.

definition: ἐλάφιον, τό, Dim. of ἔλαφος, Sm., Th. Pr. 5.19, Gp. 2.18.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.

definition: ἐλάφιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), = Ἐλαφηβολιών, at Elis, Paus. 5.13.11.

children.definition: bird, perh. heron or egret, Dionys. Av. 2.11.
plant eaten by deer as an antidote against the bite of snakes, parsnip, Pastinaca sativa, Dsc. 3.69, Plin. HN 22.79, Aët. 13.21.

children.label: II
children.definition: Dsc. 3.33; = σκόρδον, Ps.- Dsc. 2.152.

definition: ἐλαφογενές τῆς ἐλάφου ὁ μυελός, Hsch.

children.definition: deer-like, Plb. 34.10.8.
deer-headed, ἵπποι Str. 15.1.56.
deer-killing, θεά E. IT 1113 (lyr.).
deer-footed, interpol. in Hippiatr. 115.

deer, Cervus elaphus, whether male, hart or stag, Il. 3.24, etc.; or female, hind, 11.113, etc.; κεραός, ὑψίκερως, ib. 475, Od. 10.158; κεροῦσσα S. Fr. 89; ἔ. βαλιαί E. Hipp. 218 (anap.); ἔ. ἀντὶ παρθένου Lib. Ep. 785.1; κραδίην ἐλάφοιο [ἔχων] with heart of deer. i.e. a coward, Il. 1.225; φυζακινῇς ἐλάφοισιν ἐοίκεσαν 13.102, cf. Pl. La. 196e. (Fem. as a generic term, in Trag. and X. Cyn. 9.11, 10.22, cf. αἱ ἔ. τὰ κέρατα ἀποβάλλουσιν Arist. HA 611a27.)

children.label: II
children.definition: κέρας ἐλάφου hartshorn, Gp. 13.8.2.

children.label: III
children.definition: deerskin, ἐλάφου πήρα Longus 3.15.

children.label: IV
children.definition: cake, Ath. 14.649e.

children.label: V
children.definition: figure of a deer used as a weight, IG 5(2).125 ( Tegea, ii A.D.). ( -φος as in ἔρι-φος, etc., ἐλα- from ἐλṇ-, cf. ἐλλός (from *ἐλνός), Lith. élnis ‘stag’.)
garlic, Ps.- Dsc. 2.152.
deer-hunting, AP 6.253.8 ( Crin.).
tattooed with figure of a deer, Lys. 13.19.
lightness: levity, 2 Ep.Cor. 1.17.

children.label: II
children.definition: alleviation, Aret. CD 2.2.

children.label: III
children.definition: Suid.
make light: hence, lift up, carry, Coluth. 29, 156; Ep. 3 sg. impf. -ίζεσκε, κούρην Mosch. 2.130; ἐ. ἑαυτὸν ὑψοῦ Ael. NA 9.52; πτεροῖς ἑαυτήν Plu. Fort.Rom. 2.317e.
make light of, scorn, Archil. 87, cf. Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be light and nimble, E. Fr. 530.8, Call. Del. 115, Anyt. ap. Poll. 5.48, Opp. C. 1.85.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., to be relieved of forced contributions, IG 5(1).1146.28 ( Gythium, i B.C.).

definition: ἐλάφριος, ὁ (sc. μήν), month at Cnidus, SIG 953.85.

children.definition: of light soil, Gp. 3.3.11.
light-minded, Phoc. 9, Nonn. D. 10.247.

definition: ἐλαφρός, ά, όν, and in Pi. N. 5.20 ός, όν: (v. ἐλαχύς);—

children.definition: light in weight, τόν οἱ ἐ. ἔθηκε (sc. λᾶαν) Il. 12.450; ξύλου ἐλαφρότερα Hdt. 3.23; πῦρ Parm. 8.57; opp. βαρύς, Pl. Ti. 63c, etc.; in Epitaphs, γαῖαν ἔχοις ἐλαφράν ‘sit tibi terra levis’, Epigr.Gr. 195 ( Vaxos), cf. Sammelb. 315. Adv., τά (sc. δένδρεα) οἱ πλώοιεν ἐλαφρῶς Od. 5.240.

light to bear, easy, καί κεν ἐλαφρότερος πόλεμος Τρώεσσι γένοιτο Il. 22.287; συμφορὰν ἐλαφροτέραν καταστῆσαι Antipho 3.3.12; πόνος -ότερος ἑαυτοῦ συνηθείῃ γίνεται Democr. 241: later, Comp. ἐλαφρώτερον ἄλγος Max. 173; ἐλαφρόν [ἐστι] ʼtis light, easy, Pi. N. 7.77, A. Pr. 265, etc.; easy to understand, [ προβλήματα] ἐ. καὶ πιθανά Plu. Sanit. 2.133e, cf. D.Chr. 18.11; ἐν ἐλαφρῷ ποιήσασθαί τι to make light of a thing, Hdt. 3.154; οὐκ ἐν ἐ. ποιεῖσθαι Id. 1.118; οὐκ ἐν ἐ. no light matter, Theoc. 22.212. Adv. -ρῶς, φέρειν ζυγόν to bear it lightly, Pi. P. 2.93.

data.quote: καί κεν ἐλαφρότερος πόλεμος Τρώεσσι γένοιτο

children.definition: light of digestion, Plu. Sanit. 2.137a.
shallow, διάπλους Peripl.M.Rubr. 55; δῖναι ib. 40.
Act., ease-giving, B. Fr. 8, Theoc. 2.92.

children.label: II
children.definition: light in moving, nimble, γυῖα δʼ ἔθηκεν ἐ. Il. 5.122; ἦ μάλʼ ἐ. ἀνήρ 16.745; ἐλαφρότατος ποσσί 23.749; χεῖρες . . ἐπαΐσσονται ἐ. ib. 628; κίρκος . . ἐλαφρότατος πετεηνῶν 22.139, Od. 13.87; [ ἵπποι] ἐλαφρότατοι θείειν 3.370; ἐλαφραῖς πτερύγων ῥιπαῖς A. Pr. 125 (anap.); ἐ. ποδί ib. 281 (anap.); γονάτων ἐλαφρὸν ὁρμάν Pi. N. 5.20; ἐ. ποδῶν ἴχνιʼ ἀειράμεναι Fr.anon. IEG (West) 11; ἐλαφρὰ ἡλικία the age of active youth, X. Mem. 3.5.27; ἐλαφροί, οἱ, light troops, Id. An. 4.2.27 (restricted to cavalry who fight at close quarters, Ascl. Tact. 1.3): metaph., πόλιας θῆκεν ἐλαφροτέρας made them easier in condition, Epigr.Gr. 905 ( Gortyn). Adv. -ρῶς nimbly, Ar. Ach. 217; ὀρχεῖσθαι πυρρίχην X. An. 6.1.12.

children.label: III
children.definition: light-minded, unsteady, fickle, πᾶν πλῆθός ἐστιν ἐ. Plb. 6.56.11; ἐ. λύσσα light-headed madness, E. Ba. 851.

children.label: b
children.definition: gentle, mild, σφᾶς αὐτοὺς -οτάτους τοῖς συνοῦσι παρέχοντας Isoc. 12.31, cf. Pl. Ep. 360c.
small, ποταμός Plb. 16.17.7; of small power or strength, πόλεις Id. 5.62.6.
relieved of a burden, ψυχὴ ἐ. καὶ διʼ αὑτῆς Plot. 4.3.32.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Ἐλαφρός· Ζεὺς ἐν Κρήτῃ, Hsch.
lightness, nimbleness, Pl. Lg. 795e, Plu. Lyc. 17, al.
low rate of interest, IGRom. 4.292.4 ( Pergam., ii B.C.).
Hsch. s.v. ἀλεγύνεται.
make light, lighten, πόλεμον Jul. Or. 1.1Sc, cf. Babr. 111.6 ( Pass.), Aq. Jb. 39.34 (40.4).
relieve, ἀνίας Eus.Mynd. 1; κεφαλήν Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.47 ( b). 1:— Pass., ἐλαφρυνθήσεται τοῦ ὄγκου Hippiatr. 126.

children.label: b
children.definition: relieve of fiscal burdens, ἑαυτὸν ἐ. τῆς συντελείας Just. Nov. 43.1.2:— Pass., ibid.

definition: ἐλαχία ἐδάρη (Cret.), Hsch. ἐλαχίζει· πλανᾶται, Id.

children.definition: fewest times, least often, Hp. Fract. 42.
minute, infinitesimal, μέγεθος Diog.Oen. 2.

definition: ἐλάχιστος [ ᾰ], η, ον, Sup. of ἐλαχύς: Comp. ἐλάσσων (q.v.):—

children.definition: smallest, least, freq. with a neg., γέρας, δύναμις οὐκ ἐ., h.Merc. 573, Hdt. 7.168, etc.; λόγου ἐλαχίστου of least account, Id. 1.143; ἐλαχίστου ἐδέησε διαφθεῖραι narrowly missed destroying them, Th. 2.77; περὶ ἐλαχίστου ποιεῖσθαι Pl. Ap. 30a; παρʼ ἐλάχιστον ἐποίησεν αὐτοὺς ἀφαιρεθῆναι D. 17.22.
shortest, διʼ ἐλαχίστου (sc. χρόνου) Th. 3.39; διʼ ἐλαχίστης βουλῆς with shortest deliberation, Id. 1.138.
fewest, Pl. R. 378a; ἐ. τὸν ἀριθμόν Arist. Pol. 1312a30; ἐν ἐλαχίστοις δυσίν between two at least. Id. EN 1131a15.
ἐλάχιστα καὶ μέγιστα minima and maxima, Apollon.Perg. Con. 1 Praef.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὸ ἐλάχιστον, τοὐλάχιστον, at the least, Hdt. 2.13, X. An. 5.7.8, D. 4.21; ἐλάχιστα least of any one, Th. 1.70; ὡς ἐ. as little as possible, Pl. Phd. 63d.

children.label: III
children.definition: ἐλάχιστος came a new Comp. ἐλαχιστότερος less than the least, ἐ. πάντων ἁγίων Ep.Eph. 3.8: Sup. ἐλαχιστότατος very least of all, S.E. M. 3.54, 9.406.
exiguitas, Gloss.
short-backed, prob. in Pi. Pae. 4.14.
short-finned, of the dolphin, Pi. P. 4.17.

small, short, mean, little: old Ep. Positive, whence ἐλάσσων, ἐλάχιστος are formed: in early Ep. only fem., h.Ap. 197, v.l. in Od. 9.116, 10.509 (v. λάχεια): in later Ep., Archyt.Amphiss. 2, Euph. 11, Nic. Th. 324, Opp. C. 3.480, Nonn. D. 37.314: neut. ἐλαχὺ σκάφος AP 7.498 (Antip.). ( legṷh- or lengṷh-, cf. Lat. leuis, Lith. leñgvas ‘light’.)

definition: ἐλάω, Ion. ἐλόω, poet. pres. for ἐλαύνω; v. ἐλαύνω init.

children.definition: PLond. 5.1769 (vi A.D.).

definition: ἔλδομαι and ἐέλδομαι, poet. Verb, only pres. and impf.,

children.definition: wish, long, c. inf., Il. 13.638, Od. 4.162, Pi. O. 1.4: c. gen., long for, σὴν ἄλοχον τῆς αἰὲν ἐέλδεαι Od. 5.210; ἐλδόμεναι πεδίοιο (of mules) eager to reach it, Il. 23.122: c.acc., desire, ἑὸν αὐτοῦ χρεῖος ἐελδόμενος Od. 1.409, cf. Il. 5.481: abs., νόστησας ἐελδομένοισι μάλʼ ἡμῖν Od. 24.400:— Pass. only once, νῦν τοι ἐελδέσθω πόλεμος be war now welcome to thee, Il. 16.494.

definition: ἔλδωρ, Hdn.Gr. 2.770 ( ἕλδ- ib. 938 cod.), Ep. ἐέλδωρ, τό,

children.definition: wish, longing, desire, Il. 1.41, Hes. Sc. 36, etc.: fem., Ibyc. 18 (s.v.l.).
reed-warbler, Salicaria arundinacea, Arist. HA 616b12: ἔλεια, Call. Fr. 100c. 14; cf. ἐλεᾶς.

definition: ἐλεαίρω, Ep. impf. ἐλεαίρεσκον Il. 24.23: aor. 1 ἐλέηρα A.R. 4.1308, Sammelb. 2134:—

children.definition: ἐλεέω, take pity on, τινά Il. 6.407, Od. 10.399, etc.— Ep. word, used by Ar. Eq. 793 (anap.), Luc. Trag. 305.
bird, perh. = ἐλέα, Ar. Av. 302.
seneschal or steward, PCair.Zen. 59.5, 71.1 (iii B.C.), dub. in Ath. 4.171b: but, = μάγειρος, acc. to Et.Gud., where it is distd. from ἐδέατρος (q.v.).

definition: ἐλεάω, later form of ἐλεέω, EM 327.29, LXX Pr. 21.26.

children.definition: to be wrathful, wanton, violent, EM 152.50, 327.6.
Str. 13.1.48, Plu. Sol. 8, Heph. 1.5, al.
elegiac, πεντάμετρον D.H. Comp. 25, cf. Heph. 1.5; written in distichs, ἐπίνικον Ath. 4.144e, etc.

definition: ἐλεγειδάριον, τό, Dim. of ἐλεγεῖον, Petron. 109: also ἐλεγ-είδιον, τό, Pers. 1.51.

children.definition: Suid.
writer of elegies, AP 9.248 tit.
distich consisting of hexameter and pentameter, Critias 4.3D., Th. 1.132, Arist. Po. 1447b12.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἐλεγεῖα, τά, elegiac poem or inscription, merely in reference to the metre, not to the subject, Pl. R. 368a, Arist. Rh. 1375b32, Lycurg. 142, D. 59.98; even in two hexameters, Pherecr. 153.7; sg., Ps.- Hdt. Vit.Hom. 36.
lament, elegy, Paus. 10.7.5, Luc. Tim. 46; cf. ἐλεγεῖα· τὰ ἐπιτάφια ποιήματα, Hsch.: in sg., D.S. 11.14, D.H. 1.49, Plu. Them. 8, etc.

children.label: III
children.definition: a single line in an elegiac inscription, prop. the pentameter, Id. Mus. 2.1141a, Heph. 15.14.
elegiac poet, Arist. Po. 1447b14, Ath. 14.632d.
elegiac, δίστιχον Ael. VH 1.17.

definition: ἐλεγίαμβος, ὁ, the verse _⏑⏑_⏑⏑_⏑_⏑_⏑, Mar.Vict. p.145K.

children.definition: fish, Arist. HA 610b6.
one must refute, Pl. Lg. 905d; one must reject, disapprove, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. inc. 23.13.

children.label: b
children.definition: one must test, Onos. 1.19.

children.label: c
children.definition: one must convict, τινά τινος Them. Or. 21.253a.
ἐλεγκτέος, α, ον, to be refuted, Str. 2.1.35.
one who convicts or detects, τῶν ἀποκτεινάντων Antipho 2.4.3.

fond of cross-questioning or examining, Pl. Sph. 216b, etc.; ὁ ἐ. ἐκεῖνος that cross-questioner, Id. Tht. 200a; fond of reproving, critical, τῶν ἁμαρτανομένων Arist. Rh. 1381a31, cf. Longin. 4.1 ( Sup.); ἐ. βίος Jul. Or. 6.191a. Adv. -κῶς X. Smp. 4.2, etc.: Sup., Luc. Demon. 55.
refutative, of indirect modes of proof such as the reductio ad absurdum, ἐνθυμήματα Arist. Rh. 1396b25. Adv. -κῶς Alex.Aphr. in Metaph. 272.32.
-κά, τά, means of detecting, πάθους Alex.Trall. 1.15.
fit to be refuted or worthy of reproof, Hsch.

definition: ἐλεγμός, ὁ, = ἔλεγξις, LXX Ps. 149.7 (pl.), al., 2 Ep.Ti. 3.16.

children.definition: testing a wifeʼs fidelity, ποταμός AP 9.125.
wrangler, pun on the name of the philosopher Alexinus, D.L. 2.109.
refuting, reproving, LXX Jb. 21.4, al.; πικρὸς πρὸς τὰς ἐ. Philostr. VA 2.22 (pl.).
conviction, παρανομίας 2 Ep.Pet. 2.16.

song, melody, orig. accompanied by the flute, cf. ἄλυρος ἔ. E. Hel. 185 (lyr.), IT 146 (lyr.); Ἀσίας ἔ. ἰήϊος Id. Hyps.Fr. 3(1)iii9; so Ἔλεγοι, title of a νόμος αὐλῳδικός, Plu. Mus. 2.1132d; of the song of the nightingale, Ar. Av. 218 (pl.); ἔλεγον οἶτον, of the halcyon, E. IT 1091 (lyr.); later, lament, song of mourning, A.R. 2.782.

children.label: II
children.definition: poem in elegiac distichs, Call. Fr. 121; ἱλαροὶ ἔ. AP 10.19 ( Apollonid.). (Commonly derived from ἒ ἒ λέγειν, to cry woe! woe! EM 326.49.)
reproach, disgrace, Il. 22.100, al., A.R. 3.1114 (pl.), Q.S. 1.22.
worthy of reproof; of men, cowardly, ἐλεγχέες Il. 4.242, 24.239: irreg. Sup. ἐλέγχιστος 2.285, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: reproachful, μῦθος Nonn. D. 40.35.

definition: ἐλέγχιον, τό, Dim. of ἔλεγχος (B) IV, Gloss.

children.definition: like a refutation, Arist. SE 174b18, 175a40.

reproach, disgrace, dishonour, δὴ γὰρ ἔλεγχος ἔσσεται εἴ κεν νῆας ἕλῃ κορυθαίολος Ἕκτωρ Il. 11.314; ἡμῖν δʼ ἂν ἐλέγχεα ταῦτα γένοιτο Od. 21.329, cf. Pi. N. 3.15; of men, the abstr. being put for the concrete, κάκʼ ἐλέγχεα base reproaches to your name, Il. 5.787, al., Hes. Th. 26; ἐλέγχεα alone, Il. 24.260.

data.quote: δὴ γὰρ ἔλεγχος ἔσσεται εἴ κεν νῆας ἕλῃ κορυθαίολος Ἕκτωρ
ἡμῖν δʼ ἂν ἐλέγχεα ταῦτα γένοιτο

children.definition: argument of disproof or refutation, πολύδηρις ἔ. Parm. 1.36, cf. Pl. Phdr. 276a; ὁ ἔ. συναγωγὴ τῶν ἀντικειμένων ἐστίν Arist. Rh. 1410a22, cf. 1396b26; ἔ. δὲ συλλογισμὸς μετʼ ἀντιφάσεως τοῦ συμπεράσματος Id. SE 165a2, cf. APr. 66b11; ἐλέγχου ἄγνοια, ignoratio elenchi, Id. SE 168a18; ὅταν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐ. πιέζωνται Phld. D. 3.8.

data.quote: ὁ ἔ. συναγωγὴ τῶν ἀντικειμένων ἐστίν
ἔ. δὲ συλλογισμὸς μετʼ ἀντιφάσεως τοῦ συμπεράσματος

children.label: II
children.definition: cross-examining, testing, scrutiny, esp. for purposes of refutation, οὐκ ἔχει ἔλεγχον does not admit of disproof, Hdt. 2.23; τῶνδʼ ἔλεγχον, abs., as a test of this, S. OT 603; τὰ ψευδῆ ἔλεγχον ἔχει Th. 3.53; ἔ. παραδοῦναί τινι to give him an opportunity of refuting, Pl. Phdr. 273c; δόμεν τι βασάνῳ ἐς ἔ. to submit it to scrutiny, Pi. N. 8.21; χρυσὸς νόθου ἀρετῆς ἔ. Com.Adesp. 195; ἀρετῆς ἔ. δοῦναι a proof or test of it, And. 1.150; ἔ. διδόναι τοῦ βίου to give an account of oneʼs life, Pl. Ap. 39c; οἱ ἔ. περὶ ὀρφανῶν Is. 4.22; τὸ πρᾶγμα τὸν ἔ. δώσει D. 4.15; ἔ. ποιεῖν τινός to test it, Ar. Ra. 786; ἔ. ποιήσασθαι τῶν πεπραγμένων Antipho 1.7; ἔ. λαβεῖν τινός make trial of it, ib. 12; ἐλέγχους ἀποδέχεσθαι to admit tests, Lys. 19.6; ἐλέγχους προσφέρειν to allege them, Ar. Lys. 484; διάπειρα βροτῶν ἔ. Pi. O. 4.20; οὐδὲ ἔ. παρασχὼν οὐδὲ βάσανον Antipho 2.4.7; ἔ. διδόναι And. 2.4; εἰς ἔ. πεσεῖν to be convicted, E. Hipp. 1310, cf. HF 73; δεικνυμένων ἐ. Id. Heracl. 905 (lyr.); οὔτʼ εἰς ἔ. χειρὸς οὐδʼ ἔργου μολών S. OC 1297; εἰς ἔ. ἐξιέναι to proceed to the proof, put to the test, Id. Ph. 98; or, to be put to the proof, Id. Fr. 105; ἐξελθεῖν E. Alc. 640; εἰς ἔ. ἰέναι περί τινος Pl. Phdr. 278c; εἰς ἔ. ἔρχεσθαί τινος Philem. 93.3; καταστῆναι εἰς ἔ. καὶ λόγον Isoc. 12.150; ἔ. φεύγειν Antipho 5.38; οἱ περὶ Παυσανίαν ἔ. the evidence on which he was convicted, Th. 1.135; πίστις πραγμάτων ἔ. οὐ βλεπομένων Ep.Hebr. 11.1.

data.quote: οὔτʼ εἰς ἔ. χειρὸς οὐδʼ ἔργου μολών

children.label: III
children.definition: Ἔλεγχος personified, Men. 545, Luc. Pseudol. 4.

children.label: b
children.definition: Conscience, τὸ συνειδὸς ἔ. ἀδέκαστος Ph. 1.236; ἔ. κατάλογον ποιεῖται τῶν ἁμαρτημάτων [τῆς ψυχῆς] ib. 291.

children.label: IV
children.definition: catalogue, inventory, Gloss., Suet. Gramm. 8 (pl.).

children.label: V
children.definition: drop-pearl, Plin. HN 9.113, Juv. 6.459.

definition: ἐλέγχω, Od. 21.424, etc.: fut. ἐλέγξω Ar. Nu. 1043, etc.: aor. ἤλεγξα Il. 9.522, etc.:— Pass., fut. ἐλεγχθήσομαι Antipho 2.4.10, X. Mem. 1.7.2: aor. ἠλέγχθην Antipho l.c., Pl. Grg. 458a, etc.: pf. ἐλήλεγμαι Id. Lg. 805c: 3 sg. ἐλήλεγκται Antipho l.c. ( ἐξ-ηλεγμένοι is f.l. in Lys. 6.44): plpf. ἐξ-ελήλεγκτο D. 32.27:—

children.definition: disgrace, put to shame, μῦθον ἐ. treat a speech with contempt, Il. 9.522; ἐ. τινά put one to shame, Od. 21.424.—This usage is only Ep.

children.label: II
children.definition: cross-examine, question, Hdt. 2.115, Pl. Ap. 18d, etc.; μὴ ʼλεγχε τὸν πονοῦντα A. Ch. 919; φύλαξ ἐλέγχων φύλακα S. Ant. 260; τί ταῦτʼ ἄλλως ἐλέγχεις ; Id. OT 333, cf. 783; ἔλεγχʼ, ἐλέγχου Ar. Ra. 857; ἐ. τινὰ περί τινος Id. Pl. 574; ἕνεκά τινος Antiph. 207.10; τὰς ἀρχὰς βασάνοις χρώμενοι ἐλεγχόντων Pl. Lg. 946c: c. acc. et inf., accuse one of doing, E. Alc. 1058:— Pass., to be convicted, Hdt. 1.24, 117; ἐλεγχόμενοι εἴ τι περιγένοιτο τῶν χρημάτων D. 35.36, cf. Pl. Prt. 331c, 331d: with part., ἐλεγχθεὶς διαφθείρας Antipho 2.3.9, cf. 2.4.10; ἐλεγχθήσεται γελοῖος ὤν X. Mem. 1.7.2.

data.quote: ἐλεγχόμενοι εἴ τι περιγένοιτο τῶν χρημάτων

children.definition: test, bring to the proof, ἀνδρῶν ἀρετὰν παγκρατὴς ἐλέγχει ἀλάθεια B. Fr. 10.2; πρᾶγμʼ ἐ. A. Ag. 1351 ( Pass., τὸ πρᾶγμʼ ἐλεγχθέν Ar. Ec. 485); λόγον Pl. Sph. 242b ( Pass., Id. Tht. 161e): with subject. clause, ἐ. τινά, εἰ . ., A. Ch. 851, Ar. Eq. 1232.
prove, τοῦτο ἐ. ὡς . . Pl. Phdr. 273b, cf. Sph. 256c: abs., bring convincing proof, ὡς ἡ ἀνάγκη ἐ. Hdt. 2.22; αὐτὸ τὸ ἔργον ἐ. Th. 6.86; περί τινος D. 21.5.
refute, confute, τινά or τι, Pl. Grg. 470c, al., D. 28.2, Luc. Nigr. 4:— Pass., Pl. Tht. 162a; χρυσὸς κληῖδας ἐλέγχει proves that they avail not, AP 5.216 ( Paul.Sil.).

children.label: b
children.definition: put right, correct, prove by a reductio ad impossibile, ὅσα ἔστιν ἀποδεῖξαι, ἔστι καὶ ἐλέγξαι τὸν θέμενον τὴν ἀντίφασιν τοῦ ἀληθοῦς Arist. SE 170a24; παράδοξα ἐ. Id. EN 1146a23.

data.quote: ὅσα ἔστιν ἀποδεῖξαι, ἔστι καὶ ἐλέγξαι τὸν θέμενον τὴν ἀντίφασιν τοῦ ἀληθοῦς

children.definition: get the better of, στρατιὰν ὠκύτατι ἐ. Pi. P. 11.49, cf. D.P. 750, Him. Or. 1.16.
expose, τινὰ ληροῦντα Pl. Tht. 171d, cf. X. Mem. 1.7.2, M.Ant. 1.17; betray a weakness, Democr. 222.
decide a dispute, ἀνὰ μέσον τῶν δύο LXX Ge. 31.37.
octopus, Arist. HA 525a17, Henioch. 3, Artem. 2.14.
speak piteously, Hermog. Stat. 3, Id. 2.7, Herm. in Phdr. p.196A.
piteous appeal, ἐ. καὶ δείνωσις Pl. Phdr. 272a, cf. Hermog. Id. 1.1; πρὸς -λογίαν λέγειν Agatharch. 21.

definition: ἐλεεινός, ή, όν, ἐλεινός h.Cer. 284, Att. ( Eup. 25) and Trag. (v. infr.), but ἐλεεινός Men. Sam. 156 Pap.: written ἐλεηνός in LXX Da. 9.23, 10.11: ( ἔλεος):—

children.definition: finding pity, pitied, δός μʼ ἐς Ἀχιλλῆος φίλον ἐλθεῖν ἠδʼ ἐλεεινόν Il. 24.309; moving pity, piteous, 23.110, etc.; ἐλεινὸς εἰσορᾶν piteous to behold, A. Pr. 248; ἐλεινὸν ὁρᾷς thou lookest piteous, S. Ph. 1130 (lyr.); ἐσθῆτʼ ἐλεινήν Ar. Ach. 413; ἵνʼ ἐλεινοὶ τοῖς ἀνθρώποις φαίνοιντʼ εἶναι Id. Ra. 1063; ἐλεινοὶ οἱ ἀδικοῦντες Lys. 24.7; ποιῶν ἑαυτὸν ὡς ἐλεινότατον D. 21.186; -ότερος ἀνθρώποις τε καὶ θεοῖς Pl. Lg. 729e.

data.quote: δός μʼ ἐς Ἀχιλλῆος φίλον ἐλθεῖν ἠδʼ ἐλεεινόν
ἵνʼ ἐλεινοὶ τοῖς ἀνθρώποις φαίνοιντʼ εἶναι

children.label: b
children.definition: having received mercy, LXX ll.cc.
showing pity, ἐ. δάκρυον a tear of pity, Od. 8.531, 16.219, Men. l.c.; οὐδὲν ἐλεινόν no feeling of pity, Pl. Phd. 59a, cf. R. 606b.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. ἐλεεινῶς, Att. ἐλεινῶς, pitiably, S. Ph. 870, Ar. Th. 1063; ἐλεινῶς διακεῖσθαι D. 19.81: neut. pl. ἐλεεινά as Adv., Il. 2.314.

definition: ἐλεέω, impf. ἠλέουν Apollod.Com. 4.1: aor. ἠλέησα, Ep. ἐλέησα (v. infr.):— Pass., pf. ἠλέημαι Men. 595.2: ( ἔλεος):—

children.definition: to have pity on, show mercy to, ὁ δʼ ἐρύσατο καί μʼ ἐλέησεν Od. 14.279; σύ μʼ ἐλέησον S. Ph. 501, cf. Eub. 1 D., etc.; ἐλέησον αὐτῶν τὴν ὄπα Ar. Pax 400; ἐ. [τινα] ἐπὶ τοῖς ἀκουσίοις παθήμασι Antipho 1.27; τῆς τύχης τινά X.Eph. 5.4 :— Pass., Pl. Ap. 34c, R. 336e, Ax. 368d; ἵνα . . ἧττον ὑφʼ ὑμῶν ἐλεοίμην D. 27.53; ἅμʼ ἠλέηται καὶ τέθνηκεν ἡ χάρις Men. 595.2, cf. 844.

data.quote: ὁ δʼ ἐρύσατο καί μʼ ἐλέησεν
ἅμʼ ἠλέηται καὶ τέθνηκεν ἡ χάρις

children.definition: feel pity, Ar. Ach. 706.
giving alms, LXX To. 9.6.
pity, mercy, Call. Del. 152.
charity, alms, LXX To. 4.7, Ev.Matt. 6.2, D.L. 5.17.

pitiful, merciful, Od. 5.191, D. 21.101, LXX Ps. 111(112).4, Ev.Matt. 5.7; of God, LXX Ex. 34.6, al.: c.gen., Ar. Pax 425:— Comp. and Sup., ἐλεημονέστερος, -τατος, Arist. HA 608b8, Lys. 24.7. Adv. -μόνως, condemned by Poll. 8.11.

definition: ἐλεήσατο, prob. corrupt for ἐληΐσατο, Hsch.

children.definition: merciful, compassionate, Arist. Rh. 1389b8.
to be pitied, Sch. A. Pr. 355.

definition: ἐλεητύς, ύος, ἡ, Ep. and Ion.

children.definition: pity, mercy, Od. 17.451.

definition: ἐλεθαινομένη ἀκολασταίνουσα, Hsch. ἔλεια, v. ἐλέα.

children.definition: dwelling in marshes, λέων Call. Fr.anon. 748 P..

definition: ἐλειθερεῖ εὐδία, and ἐλειθερεῖς ( ἐλειτεθ- cod.) · ἐν ἡλίῳ τιθέμενοι ἢ θερμοί, Hsch.; cf. εἱληθερής.
ἑλεῖν, v. αἱρέω. ἐλεινός, v. ἐλεεινός.

children.definition: walking the marsh, marsh-dwelling, A. Pers. 39 (anap.).
marsh-born: τὸ ἑ., = ὄρυζα, Hsch.
conduit for draining marshes, CIG 2782.40 ( Aphrodisias).
marsh-mallow, Apul. Herb. 40,38 ( elaeo- codd.).
dwelling in the marsh or meadow, Νύμφαι A.R. 2.821; ποίη Orph. A. 1054; situate there, ib. 157.
Hsch.

definition: ἕλειος, ον ( α, ον Ar. Av. 244 (lyr.), Dsc. 4.52): ( ἕλος):—

children.definition: of the marsh or meadow, ἕ. ὕδωρ marsh-water, Hp. Aër. 10; ἕ. δάπεδον the surface of the meads, Ar. Ra. 352 (lyr.).

growing or dwelling in the marsh, δόναξ A. Pers. 494; τῶν Αἰγυπτίων οἱ ἕ. Th. 1.110; βίος ἕ. Arist. PA 693a15; [ ζῷα] ἕ. ib. 674b31; σχοῖνος Dsc. l.c.; ἀκτή Ps.- Dsc. 4.173; ἕλειον, τό, = asparagus, Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑλεία, ἡ, title of Artemis in Cos, Schwyzer 251 B 5.
dormouse, Myoxus glis, Arist. HA 600b12, Artem. 3.65; μύες ἐ. Edict.Diocl. 4.38.

children.label: II
children.definition: hawk, Hsch., prob. in Arist. HA 620a21.

children.label: III
children.definition: wood-worm, Aristarch. ap. Hsch.
marsh-celery, Apium graveolens, Thphr. HP 7.6.3, Dsc. 3.64.
bred in the marsh, Archestr. Fr. 15.7.
marsh-growing, κάλαμος Dion.Byz. 23.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑλείτας, ὁ, title of Apollo in Cyprus, Schwyzer 682.15.
a cry of pain, A. Pr. 877 (anap.); also an exclamation used at the ceremony of the ὠσχοφόρια, Plu. Thes. 22:—in form ἐλελελεῦ, a war-cry, Ar. Av. 364, cf. Sch.ad loc.

definition: ἐλελίζω (A), Ep. redupl. of ἑλίσσω (v. infr.), rare in pres., as Pi. O. 9.13; impf. ἠλέλιζον Hsch., poet. ἐλέλιζον Maiist. 42, Nonn. D. 2.525: mostly in aor. (v. infr.):— Pass., impf. h.Hom. 28.9: Ep. aor. ἐλέλικτο Il. 13.558: pf. ἐλέλιγμαι Cerc. 6.18:—

children.definition: whirl round, περὶ σχεδίην ἐλέλιξε [τὸ κῦμα] Od. 5.314; ἡ δʼ ἐλελίχθη [ἡ νηῦς] 12.416.

Med. and Pass., move in coils or spires, of a serpent, τὴν δʼ ἐλελιξάμενος πτέρυγος λάβεν Il. 2.316; ἐπʼ αὐτοῦ (sc. τελαμῶνος) ἐλέλικτο δράκων 11.39, cf. A.R. 4.143; σπείρας ὄφεων ἐλελιζομένη Ar. Fr. 500.

children.label: II
children.definition: Il. of an army, cause it to turn and face the enemy, rally it, σφεας ὦκʼ ἐλέλιξεν Αἴας 17.278:—in Pass., οἱ δʼ ἐλελίχθησαν 5.497, 6.106; cf. ἑλίσσω II.1.

children.label: III
children.definition: cause to vibrate, μέγαν δʼ ἐλέλιξεν Ὄλυμπον, of Zeus, ib. 1.530, cf. 8.199; φόρμιγγα ἐ. make its strings quiver, Pi. O. 9.13; ἀστεροπὰν ἐλελίξαις Id. N. 9.19:— Med., ἵππον . . ἀγωνίῳ ἐλελιζόμενος ποδὶ μίμεο Simon. 29:— Pass., quake, tremble, quiver, ἐλελίχθη γυῖα Il. 22.448; ἐλέλικτο, of a brandished spear, 13.558; ἀμφὶ δὲ πέπλος ἐλελίζετο ποσσίν h.Cer. 183; μέγας δʼ ἐλελίζετʼ Ὄλυμπος h.Hom. l.c.; φόρμιγξ ἐλελιζομένα Pi. P. 1.4. (In Hom. ἐλελ- may have been substituted for ἐϝελ- ( ϝεϝελ- in ἐλέλικτο); cf. ἑλίσσω.)

definition: ἐλελίζω (B), aor. ἠλέλιξα X. An. 5.2.14, Ep. ἐλ- Call. Del. 137:—

children.definition: cry ἐλελεῦ, hence, raise the battle-cry, τῷ Ἐνυαλίῳ X. An. 1.8.18: generally, raise a loud cry, E. Ph. 1514 (lyr.); of a shield, ring, Call. l.c.:— Med., of the nightingale, trill her lay of sorrow, E. Hel. 1111 (lyr.): c. acc., Ἴτυν ἐλελιζομένη trilling her lament for Itys, Ar. Av. 213 (lyr., but punctuation is dub.).
flavoured with sage, Dsc. 5.61.
salvia, Salvia triloba, Thphr. HP 6.1.4, 6.2.5.
violent shaking, Hsch.

definition: ἐλελίχθων, ον, gen. ονος, ( ἐλελίζω A)

children.definition: earth-shaking, τετραορία Pi. P. 2.4; Ἐλέλιχθον, i.e. Poseidon, ib. 6.50:—in S. Ant. 153 Dionysus is called ὁ Θήβας ἐ. because the ground shook beneath the feet of his dancing bands.

definition: ἔλεμος σπέρμα ὅπερ ἕψοντες Λάκωνες ἐσθίουσιν, Hsch.

children.definition: ship-destroying, epith. of Helen, prob. for ἑλένας, A. Ag. 689 (lyr.).
torch, Hsch.; cf. ἑλάνη.
corposant, St. Elmoʼs fire, Lyd. Ost. 5.

children.label: II
children.definition: wicker-basket, to carry the sacred utensils at the feast of the Brauronian Artemis, Poll. 10.191:—hence ἑλενηφόρια, the feast itself, ibid.
feast in honour of Helen in Laconia, Hsch.
calamint, Calamintha incana, Chaerem. 14.12, Thphr. HP 6.6.2, Dsc. 1.29.
elecampane, Inula Helenium, ib. 28.

definition: ἑλένιος ἀγγεῖον χωροῦν τέταρτον, Hsch. ἑλενοί· κλήματα τὰ τῶν ἀμπέλων, Id.; cf. ἕλινος.

children.definition: slayer of Helen, Sch. E. Or. 1140.
sacrificial cook at Delos, Ath. 4.173a.
marsh-bred, σέλινον Il. 2.776, Nic. Th. 597.
Lys. Fr. 28. (Expld. either fr. ἐλεός I or as, = οἱ τὰ ἕλη κόπτοντες.)
piteously, Hes. Op. 205: Comp. -ώτερον Hsch.
kitchen table, dresser, in pl., Il. 9.215, Od. 14.432:—later ἐλεόν, τό, Ar. Eq. 152, 169.

children.label: II
children.definition: owl, Arist. HA 592b11.

pity, mercy, compassion, Il. 24.44, etc.: also in pl., Pl. R. 6c6c, D. 25.83; μʼ ἔ. τινος ἐσῆλθε pity for . ., E. IA 491; ἔλεον ποιήσασθαι ἐπί τινι D. 24.111; ἐλέου τυχεῖν παρά τινος Antipho 1.27:—later ἔλεος, τό, Plb. 1.88.2, LXX Ge. 19.19, etc.:pl., ἐλέη, τά, ib. Ps. 16(17).7; ἐ. ποιεῖν μετά τινος ib. Ge. 24.12, al. (but masc. is also found, ib. Ps. 83 ( 84). 12, Plb. 33.11.3, Agatharch. 83, Phld. Rh. 1.65 S., Ep.Jac. 2.13, etc.).

children.label: II
children.definition: S. OC 260; at Epidaurus, IG 4.1282; Ἔ. ἐπιεικὴς θεός Timocl. 31.

children.label: III
children.definition: object of compassion, piteous thing, E. Or. 832.

definition: ἐλεπόδιον εἶδός τι βάναυσος (fort. βαλαυστίου), Hsch. ἐλέποκες· ἰχθὺς ὅμοιος φυκίδι, Id.

children.definition: city-destroying, epith. of Helen, A. Ag. 689 (lyr.); of Iphigenia, E. IA 1476 (lyr.), 1511 (lyr.); of Lamia, Com.Adesp. 303.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., engine for sieges, invented by Demetrius Poliorcetes, D.S. 20.48, Plu. Demetr. 21, Ph. Bel. 95.39, Vitr. 10.16.4, etc.; ἄνευ μηχανῆς καὶ ἑ. Alciphr. 3.45: pl., ἑ. μηχαναί D.H. 9.68.
ἑ. τῆς Ἑλλάδος Hp. Ep. 11; also ἡ τῶν ἀνοσίων ἑ. τοῦτο (sc. πένθος) Ph. 2.191.
marsh-lands, meadow, A.R. 1.1266.
that can be taken or caught, Il. 9.409, Max.Tyr. 18.3.
Procop. Pers. 1.16.

definition: Ἐλευθεραί, αἱ, Eleutherae, on frontier of Attica and Boeotia:— hence Ἐλευθερεύς, έως, ὁ, title of Dionysus, Paus. 1.38.8, etc.

children.definition: freedom, liberty, Pi. P. 1.61, Hdt. 1.62, 95; ἐλευθερίας φῶς A. Ch. 809 (lyr.), cf. 863 (anap.); διʼ ἐλευθερίας μόλις ἐξῆλθες, i.e. μόλις ἠλευθερώθης, S. El. 1509 (anap.); ὑπῆρξαν ἐλευθερίας τῆ Ἑλλάδι And. 1.142; freedom from a thing, ἀπὸ πασῶν ἀρχῶν Pl. Lg. 698a; τινός Id. R. 329c, cf. AP 6.228 ( Adaeus).

children.label: b
children.definition: manumission, ἡ εἰκοστὴ τῶν ἐ., = Lat. vicesima manumissionum, BGU 326ii 11 (ii A.D.).
licence, ἀκολασία καὶ ἐ. Pl. Grg. 492c; of Diogenes, Jul. Or. 6.185c.
dance, S.E. M. 1.293.

festival of Liberty, held every four years at Plataea, in memory of the battle there, Posidipp. 29, D.S. 11.29, Paus. 9.2.6, etc.; at Syracuse, in memory of the restoration of the republic, D.S. 11.72; at Samos, in honour of Eros, Erxias ap. Ath. 13.562a: generally, ἐ. θύειν Henioch. 5.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: thanksgiving for liberty, IG 9(2).1034 (Thess.).

speak or act like a freeman, Pl. Lg. 701e, Arist. Pol. 1314a8, Ph. 1.380; ἐ. τοῖς λόγοις Plu. Lib.educ. 2.6e; πρός τινα Luc. Cat. 1; ἐλευθεριάξαντας ( Dor. aor.) Epimenid. ap. D.L. 1.113; to be free, ἀπὸ τοῦ πλούτου Crat. Ep. 8; esp. from public burdens, PFlor. 382.7 (iii A.D.): c.gen., πολυτελείας Chaerem. ap. Porph. Abst. 4.8.
free, πολιτεία Pl. Lg. 701e ( Sup.); τὸ ἐ. καὶ ἀνελεύθερον ib. 919e.

definition: ἐλευθέριος, ον, also α, ον X. Smp. 8.16:—

children.definition: speaking or acting like a freeman, free-spirited, ἐ. καὶ δημωφελής Democr. 282, etc.; ἀνδρεῖοι καὶ ἐ. Pl. Lg. 635d; opp. δουλοπρεπής, X. Mem. 2.8.4 ( Comp.); of certain animals, as the lion, ἐ. καὶ ἀνδρεῖα καὶ εὐγενῆ Arist. HA 488b16.

children.label: b
children.definition: freely giving, bountiful, ἐ. εἰς χρήματα X. Smp. 4.15 ( Comp.), cf. Arist. EN 1120a8, etc.

fit for a freeman, liberal, πτηνῶν θήρας . . ἔρως οὐ σφόδρα ἐ. Pl. Lg. 823e, cf. Grg. 485b; ἐπιστήμη Id. Ax. 369b ( Sup.); τέχναι Plu. Sanit. 2.122d; βίος Men 408 (dub.); διαγωγή Arist. Pol. 1339b5; παιδεία ib. 1338a32; πρᾶξις, ἔργα, ib. 1263b12, Oec. 1344a28; ἡδοναὶ -ώταται, κινήσεις -ώτεραι, Id. EN 1118b4, Pol. 1340b10; τὸ ἐ.,= ἐλευθεριότης, X. Mem. 3.10.5 : prov., ὕδωρ πίοιμι ἐ., i.e. may I become free, because slaves set free at Argos were then first allowed to drink of the spring Κυνάδρα, Antiph. 25.
frank, noble, εὐπρεπής τε ἰδεῖν καὶ ἐ. X. Mem. 2.1.22, cf. Lac. 11.3 ( Comp.); ἵππος Id. Eq. 10.17.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. -ίως, ζῆν Arist. Pol. 1326b31; τεθραμμένους Isoc. 4.49, 7.43 (prob.): Comp. -ιώτερον, ζῆν X. Mem. 1.6.3: Sup. -ιώτατα ib. 4.8.1.

children.label: III
children.definition: Ζεὺς Ἐ. Zeus the Deliverer, Pi. O. 12.1, Simon. 140.4, Hdt. 3.142, etc.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Ἐ., ὁ (sc. μήν), = Ἐλευθεριών, SIG 1044.26.
the character of an ἐλευθέριος, esp. freeness in giving, liberality, Pl. R. 402c, Arist. EN 1119b22, etc.; ἡ τῶν χρημάτων ἐ. Pl. Tht. 144d: generally, generosity, ἡ ἐ. τῆς ὑπουργίας Plu. Pomp. 73.

definition: Ἐλευθεριών, ῶνος, ὁ(sc. μήν), name of month at Halicarnassus, Inscr.Cos 13.

children.definition: claiming freedom, λόγος Him. Ecl. 7 tit.
free of speech, Vett.Val. 16.31.
free quarrymen, PPetr. 3p.105 (iii B.C); δεκάταρχοι τῶν ἐ. ib. 2p.33 (iii B.C.).
having free children, Βενέτων δῆμος APl. 16.359.
making free, θεός Ph. 1.401; δόγμα Arr. Epict. 4.1.176; creating freedom, Plot. 6.8.12.
for selling a freeman as a slave, Poll. 3.78.
disposition of a freeman, condemned by Poll. 3.119.
worthy of a freeman, Pl. Alc. 1.135c. Adv. -πῶς ibid.

definition: ἐλεύθερος, α, ον ( ος, ον A. Ag. 328, E. El. 868): later ἐλαύθερος BCH 22.76 (Delph.); Elean ἐλεύθαρος Schwyzer 416.3:—

children.definition: free, Hom. has the word only in Il. in two phrases, ἐλεύθερον ἦμαρ the day of freedom, i.e. freedom, Il. 6.455, 16.831, al.; and κρητὴρ ἐλεύθερος the cup drunk to freedom, 6.528; ἐ. πιοῦσαν οἶνον ἀποθανεῖν Xenarch. 5 codd. Ath. (fort. -ριον, cf. ἐλευθέριος I.2); of persons, Alc. Supp. 25.11, Hdt. 1.6, A. Pr. 50, S. Aj. 1020, Th. 8.15, etc.: Comp., X. Cyr. 8.3.21: Sup., Id. Hier. 1.16; τὸ ἐ. freedom, Hdt. 7.103, etc.; τοὐλεύθερον E. Supp. 438: c.gen., free or freed from a thing, φόνου, πημάτων, φόβου, A. Eu. 603 codd., Ch. 1060, E. Hec. 869; αἰτίας Men. Sam. 272; ἔξω αἰτίας ἐ. S. Ant. 445; ἐ. ἀπʼ ἀλλήλων independent, X. Cyr. 3.2.23, Pl. Lg. 832d.

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐλευθέρα, ἡ, married woman, Ath. 13.571d; wife, POxy. 1872.8 (v/vi A.D.); but, freedwoman, IG 14.2490 ( Vienne).

children.label: c
children.definition: free, of cities, in Roman Law, BGU 316.3 (iv A.D.).

free, open to all, ἀγορά X. Cyr. 1.2.3; ἐ. φυλακή,= Lat. libera custodia, D.S. 4.46; περιωπή Ael. NA 15.5; unencumbered, of property, D. 35.21, IG 9(1).32.10 ( Stiris), SIG 364.36 ( Ephesus, iii B.C.).
ἐλεύθερον εἶναί τινι, c. inf., legally permissible, open to . ., ib. 45.42 ( Halic., v B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: fit for a freeman, free, frank, φρήν Pi. P. 2.57; ἐλευθερωτέρη ὑπόκρισις Hdt. 1.116; ἐλεύθρα βάζειν A. Pers. 593 (lyr.); ὦ μηδὲν ὑγιὲς μηδʼ ἐ. φρονῶν S. Ph. 1006; δούλη μέν, εἴρηκεν δʼ ἐ. λόγον Id. Tr. 63, cf. El. 1256; φρονήματα Pl. R. 567a; βάσανοι ἐ. tortures such as might be used to a freeman, Id. Lg. 946c (so φάσγανα E. Fr. 495.38); τὸ ἐ. Pl. Mx. 245c: freq. in Adv. -ρως, εἰπεῖν Hdt. 5.93, al.; χαίρειν . . καὶ γελᾶν ἐ. S. El. 1300; τεθραμμένους Isoc. 7.43 codd. (fort. -ερίως) ; παιδευθεὶς ἐ. Aeschin. 3.154 codd. (fort. -ερίως) ; ἐ. δούλευε, δοῦλος οὐκ ἔσει Men. 857; ἐλεύθεροι ἐλευθέρως free and like free men, Pl. Lg. 919e. (Cf. Lat. līber, fr. Ital. *loufero-(cf. Osc. Luvfreis ‘Liberiʼ), I.-E. (e)leudh-ero-: the connexion with Slav. liud, OHG. liut, etc. ‘people’ is doubtful.)

data.quote: ὦ μηδὲν ὑγιὲς μηδʼ ἐ. φρονῶν
δούλη μέν, εἴρηκεν δʼ ἐ. λόγον

children.definition: to be free of speech, A. Pr. 182 (lyr.), E. Andr. 153; in later Prose, Ph. 1.474, al.
freedom of speech, D.H. 6.72.
free-spoken, γλῶσσα A. Supp. 948.
free-souled, Tz. H. 10.620.

set free, τὰς Ἀθήνας Hdt. 5.62; Ἰωνίην Id. 4.137; πατρίδα A. Pers. 403; πόλιν Id. Ch. 1046, D. 21.144; δούλους Th. 8.15, etc.; ἐ. τὸν ἔσπλουν set the entrance free, clear it, Id. 3.51; release a debtor, Hdt. 6.59; τό γʼ εἰς ἑαυτὸν πᾶν ἐλευθεροῖ στόμα he keeps his tongue altogether free, i.e. does not commit himself by speech, S. OT 706; free from blame, acquit, τινά X. HG 1.7.26:— Pass., to be set free, Hdt. 1.95, 127, al.; τυράννων Id. 5.62; indulge in licence, Pl. R. 575a.

set free, release from, φόνου E. Hipp. 1449; χρεῶν Pl. R. 566e; ἀρότρου βοῦν Hld. 5.23; also ἐλευθεροῦντες ἐκ δρασμῶν πόδα, i.e. ceasing to flee, E. HF 1010:— Pass., τῶνδε τῶν τόπων ἐ. Pl. Phd. 114b; ἀπὸ τῶν πλουσίων Id. R. 569a.
release from, κακῶν Procop.Gaz. p.141B.
liberation, Hdt. 9.45; ἀπό τινος Th. 3.10; δούλων ἐ. ποιεῖσθαι Arist. Pol. 1315a37, cf. POxy. 48.2 (i A.D.), etc.: pl., Plu. Galb. 5.

children.label: II
children.definition: licence, Pl. R. 561a.
one must set free, Plb. 18.45.9.
liberator, Max.Tyr. 21.6, Luc. Vit.Auct. 8, D.C. 41.57.

definition: ἐλεύθω, causal of stem ἐλυθ-(cf. ἔρχομαι),

children.definition: bring, Dor. fut. ἐλευσίω· οἴσω, Hsch., Dor. 3 pl. aor. ἐλεύσαν Ibyc. Oxy. 1790.18; cf. ἐπελεύθω.

definition: ἐλευσέαν τὴν βρυωνίαν, Hsch. ( ἐλεψέαν poscit ordo).

children.definition: of Eleusis, h.Cer. 266, Hdt. 9.57, etc.; epith. of Zeus in Ionia, Hsch.; of Artemis in Sicily and Antioch, Id., Lib. Or. 11.109; but mostly of Demeter, Antim. 63, etc.; Δηὼ Ἐ. S. Ant. 1120 (lyr.); Ἐλευσείνιαι (sic) Demeter and Cora, IG 4.955.14 (Epid.): hence,

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἐλευσίνιον, τό, their temple at Eleusis, And. 1.110, IG 1(2).6.129.

children.label: III
children.definition: Ἐλευσίνια, τά, their festivals, ib. 12.5, 22.847.24, Hyp. Fr. 112, Paus. 4.33.5, etc.: prov., Ἀττικοὶ τὰ Ἐ., of groups of persons confabulating, Duris 95 J.: Lacon. Ἐλευhύνια, τά, IG 5(1).213.11 (v B.C.).

children.label: IV
children.definition: Ἐλευσίνιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of month in Crete, GDI 5183: also spelt Ἐλευσύνιος SIG 712.8 ( Olus), and so in Thera, Test.Epict. 2.7,3.3. [ σῑ, exc. in h.Cer. l.c., S. Ant. 1120 (lyr.).]
Eleusis, an old city of Attica, sacred to Demeter and Cora, first in h.Cer. 97; late Ἐλευσίν Str. 9.1.12 codd. (but Ἐλευσίς 9.1.20), Corn. ND 28.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἐλευσῖνι at Eleusis, IG 1(2).76.10, al., And. 1.111, Lys. 6.4, etc.; later ἐν Ἐ. IG 2(2).1028.11, al.: Ἐλευσῖνάδε to Eleusis, Lys. 12.52, X. HG 2.4.24: Ἐλευσῑνόθεν from Eleusis, And. 1.111, Lys. 6.45.
coming, arrival, εἰς βίον Corn. ND 28, cf. Tz. H. 7.572, Sch. A.R. 4.887, Hsch.
the Advent of Christ, Act.Ap. 7.52.
one must come, LXX 2 Ma. 6.17.

definition: ἐλεφαίρομαι, old Ep. Verb, perh. connected with ὀλοφώϊος (q. v.),

children.definition: cheat with empty hopes, said of the false dreams that come through the ivory gate (with play on ἐλέφας, cf. κραίνω) , οἱ μέν κʼ ἔλθωσι διὰ πριστοῦ ἐλέφαντος, οἵ ἐλεφαίρονται Od. 19.565: generally, cheat, overreach, ἐλεφηράμενος . . Τυδεΐδην Il. 23.388.

data.quote: οἱ μέν κʼ ἔλθωσι διὰ πριστοῦ ἐλέφαντος, οἵ ἐλεφαίρονται

children.label: II
children.definition: ἐλεφαίρετο φῦλʼ ἀνθρώπων he used to destroy them, Hes. Th. 330. ( Act. only in Hsch., who also has aor. 1 ἐλεφῆραι· ἀπατῆσαι.)
elephant-driver, Poll. 1.140.
commander of a squadron of sixteen elephants, Ascl. Tact. 9, Phylarch. 31 J., Plu. Demetr. 25, LXX 2 Ma. 14.12.
squadron of sixteen elephants, Ael. Tact. 23.
of an elephant, Dsc. 2.76.17, Opp. C. 2.500.
ivory-worker, PPar. 5 xliii.
transporting elephants (sc. νῆες), Agatharch. 83, cf. PPetr. 2p.135 (iii B.C.).
elephantiasis, Cels. 3.25, Dsc. 2.70.3, Plu. QConv. 2.731a.
suffer from elephantiasis, Phld. Rh. 2.120S., Dsc. 1.77, Ptol. Tetr. 151, Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.27.2.
of elephants, ὀδόντες IG 3.1376.
of ivory, Alc. 33.1, Ar. Eq. 1169, Pl. 815, al.; δίφρος ἐ., = Lat. sella curulis, Plb. 6.53.9 (pl.), al.; οἶκοι ἐ. LXX Am. 3.15; τὸ ἐ. the substance of ivory, Pl. Hp.Ma. 290c.
white as ivory, μέτωπον Anacreont. 15.12; τάριχος Crates 29.
Dim. of ἐλέφας, young elephant, Ael. NA 8.27.
elephant-driver, Arist. HA 497b28 (cf. Demetr. Eloc. 97), Porph. Abst. 3.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: shield of elephant-hide, App. Pun. 46.
feeding elephants, γαῖα Nonn. D. 39.26.
inlaid with ivory, δόμοι E. IA 582 (lyr.); φόρμιγξ Ar. Av. 219 (lyr.).
elephant-hunter, Agatharch. 54 (pl.), Sammelb. 4144, 4151.
care of elephants, Ael. NA 6.8.
ivory-hilted, ξιφομάχαιρα Theopomp.Com. 25; ξίφη Luc. Gall. 26.
battle of elephants, Plu. Pomp. 52.
fighting against elephants, ζῷον Str. 16.4.15, cf. D.S. 3.26.
ivory-backed, ἡνίαι Eust. 583.44.
ivory-armed, Max.Tyr. 14.6.
ivory-footed, κλίνη Pl.Com. 208; τράπεζα Luc. Gall. 14; ἐλεφαντόποδες τὰ ἐνήλατα καὶ κλιντῆρες Ph. 1.666.
ivory-cutter, Opp. C. 2.514.
the art of ivory-working, Sch. Paul.Al. P. 1.
working in ivory, ὄργανα Philostr. VA 5.20: -γός, ὁ, ivory-worker, A.D. Pron. 31.19, Them. Or. 18.224b:
ivory-working, Vett.Val. 3.23.
elephant-eater, Agatharch. 55, Str. 16.4.10.
like ivory, ὀδόντες Eust. 1877.42.
ivory-coloured, ὀδόντες Eust. 1877.36.
inlay with ivory, τράπεζα ἠλεφαντωμένη IG 1(2).283.
like an elephant, ὦτα Aret. SD 2.13.
personacia (i.e. ἄρκιον), Gloss.
inlaid with ivory, IG 2.706 A b14.

definition: ἐλέφας, αντος, ὁ ( θήλεια ἐ. Phylarch. 36J.): irreg. gen. ἐλεφάντου BCH 35.286 ( Delos, ii B.C.): dat. pl. -τοις LXX 1 Ma. 1.17 (v.l.):—

children.definition: elephant, first mentioned by Hdt. as a native of Africa, 3.114, 4.191; ἐλέφαντος ὀδόντες Id. 3.97; of the Indian elephant, first in Arist. Cael. 298a13, HA 610a15, cf. Paus. 1.12.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hom. only of elephantʼs tusk, ivory, Il. 5.583, cf. Hes. Sc. 141, Pi. O. 1.27, Pl. R. 373a, GDI 5500, etc.: Aeol. ἐλέφαις Sapph. 44.10 L.-P..

children.label: IV
children.definition: precious stone, Thphr. Lap. 37.

children.label: V
children.definition: cup, Damox. 1.1.

children.label: VI
children.definition: Apul. Herb. 36.
fish, corrupt in Hp. Vict. 2.48 ( ἀλφηστής Coraes).

definition: ἐλέχει ψηλαφᾶ, Hsch. ἐλεών· θάμνος, Id.

children.label: II
children.definition: snake called σκυτάλη, Id.
fish of the Nile, Ath. 7.312b.

definition: ἕλη, ἡ, = εἵλη, ἀλέα (B), Ar. V. 772 (Sch.Rav.), Eust. 667.22, 1573.45.

children.definition: oil-merchant, OGI 521.25 (v/vi A.D.).
Gal. 19.97 ( Pass.).

definition: ἐλήλ-, ἐλήλαμαι, ἐληλέδατο or ἐληλάδατο, v. ἐλαύνω.

senses.definition: ἐλήλῠθα, εἰλήλουθα, ἐλθεῖν, ἐλθέμεν, ἐλθέμεναι, v. ἔρχομαι.

children.definition: Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 10.4.1, Philum. ap. Aët. 9.12.

definition: ἐλθετῶς ἀντὶ τοῦ ἐλθέ, Σαλαμίνιοι, Hsch. ἐλίβοτρυς· ἄμπελός τις μέλαινα, Id.

children.definition: whirling, rolling, A. Pr. 882 (anap.); cf. εἱλίγδην.
fold, wrapping, ἱμάντων ἑλίγμασι, of straps bound round the leg, Ephipp. 14.9; στρουθωτὰ ἑ. Sophr. 100.

children.label: II
children.definition: bracelets, in pl., Hsch., prob. in Sapph. 44.8 L.-P..

children.label: III
children.definition: curl, lock of hair, AP 6.211 ( Leon.).

children.label: IV
children.definition: depression of the skull without fracture, = θλάσμα, Sor. Fract. 1.

children.label: V
children.definition: packet, σμύρνης καὶ ἀλόης v.l. in Ev.Jo. 19.39.
ἑλικοειδής, twisted, Lex. de Spir. p.195 V.

winding, convolution, of the Labyrinth, Hdt. 2.148; πολλοὺς ἑ. ἄνω καὶ κάτω πλανᾶσθαι X. Cyr. 1.3.4; of the gut, ἑ. ἔχει Arist. HA 532b7; of the Fallopian tubes, ib. 510b19; of the brain, Erasistr. ap. Gal. 5.603; of a snake, Sch. Nic. Th. 159; of dancers’ feet, Orph. H. 38.12: generally, rotatory motion, Plu. Pyth. 2.404f; ὀφθαλμῶν ἑλιγμοί rolling of eyes, Procop.Gaz. Hor. p. 151 B.; ἑ. καὶ ἀναστροφαὶ ὀργάνων Max.Tyr. 19.4: pl., the plies of a knot, Plu. Alex. 18; ῥευμάτων ἑλιγμοί Id. Caes. 19; ὀρῶν Lib. Or. 61.8.

data.quote: πολλοὺς ἑ. ἄνω καὶ κάτω πλανᾶσθαι

children.definition: Poll. 2.67.

definition: Ἐλιεύς, ὁ, title of Zeus at Thebes, Hsch.

children.definition: wreathed with a circlet, Σεμέλα Pi. Fr. 75.20; θεά Id. Pae. 3.15.
with circling orbit, epith. of the moon, Man. 4.224.
with circling rays, κύκλος, of the sun, Orph. Fr. 236.1; of the moon, Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.173.
winding: hence,

children.label: I
children.definition: the constellation of the Great Bear, from its revolving round the pole, Arat. 37, A.R. 3.1195.

children.label: II
children.definition: convolution of a spiral shell, Arist. HA 524b12, PA 680a22, al.; of the bowels, ib. 682a15; of the ear, Id. GA 781b15.

children.label: III
children.definition: crack willow, Salix fragilis, from its pliant nature, Thphr. HP 3.13.7.
spirally, Thphr. HP 3.13.1, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 19.

children.label: II
children.definition: revolving in a circle, Nonn. D. 1.195.
forked lightning, Arist. Mu. 395a27 (pl.).
with ever-moving eyes, quick-glancing, epith. of Aphrodite, h.Hom. 6.19, Hes. Th. 16, Pi. Fr. 123.5; of Alcmene, Id. P. 4.172.
with curling hair, Ar. Fr. 334 (lyr.).
describe a curve, of the Nile, Anon. Geog.Comp. 31.
running in curves, twisting, Orph. H. 9.10; circular, E. Ba. 1067 (cj. for ἕλκει δρόμον).

of winding or spiral form, [ σαυνία] D.S. 5.30; γραμμή Plu. Num. 13; of planetary orbits, Cleom. 1.4; ἔντερον Aret. SD 2.3; τόποι S.E. P. 1.126; σελήνη D.L. 7.144. Adv. -δῶς Cleom. 1.4, Dsc. 2.165, Olymp. in Mete. 13.9.
with curled horns, Hsch. s.v. ἕλικας.
with twining leaves, prob. in Sacerd. p.540.1 K.
with winding stream, Orac. ap. Paus. 4.20.1.
eddying, of water, Call. Fr. 290 ( Sup.); χορεία Hymn.Is. 155.
with twisted diadem, κούρα B. 8.62.
anything twisted: ear-ring, Ar. Fr. 320.14, Lys. 12.19, IG 2.747.5.
Apollon. Lex.Hom. s.v. ἕλικας.
coiled, τὸ ἑ. τῆς οὐρᾶς Doroth. in Cat. Cod.Astr. 2.158.

rolled, twisted, wreathed, βοῦς κεράεσσιν ἑλικτάς h.Merc. 192; δράκων S. Tr. 12, cf. Pae.Delph. 19; κισσός E. Ph. 652 codd. (lyr.); στέφανος Chaerem. 7; βόστρυχος Theodect. 6.4; κλῖμαξ ἑ. winding staircase, Callix. 1; ἑ. κύτος a wheeled ark, E. Ion 40; εἱλικτὸν κρούειν πόδα, of dancers (cf. ἑλίσσω I.3), Id. El. 180 (lyr.); σῦριγξ περὶ χεῖλος ἑλικτά Theoc. 1.129; ἑλικτά, of insects that can roll or double themselves up, Arist. PA 682b24, 692a2: Comp. ἑλικτότερος Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: tortuous, not straightforward, ἑλικτὰ κοὐδὲν ὑγιές E. Andr. 448; obscure, Lyc. 1466.
Plu. QConv. 2.648f, Nonn. D. 1.370.
thread spun from the distaff to the spindle, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: nine-stringed instrument, Aristid.Quint. 3.3, Ptol. Harm. 2.2.
Helicon, a hill in Boeotia, the seat of the Muses, Hes. Op. 639, etc.:—hence

Ἑλῐκωνιάδες (sc. παρθένοι), αἱ, dwellers on Helicon, i.e. Muses, Pi. Pae.Fr. 16.14, I. 2.34; Μοῦσαι Hes. Op. 658, Th. 1, CIG 3067.10 ( Teos):—also Ἑλῐκωνίδες Νύμφαι S. OT 1108 (lyr.); Μοῦσαι E. HF 791 (lyr.), IG 4.682.13 ( Hermione): sg., of a poetʼs reed-pen, AP 9.162.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑλικωνιάς, άδος, ἡ, = ὑάκινθος, Ps.- Dsc. 4.62.
Heliconian, of Helicon, παρθένοι Pi. I. 8(7).63.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑ. ἄναξ Il. 20.404: acc. to Sch., from Helice in Achaia, where he was especially honoured, 8.203 (but cf. Aristarch. ap. EM 547.16, h.Hom. 22.3).
threaded like a screw, Orib. 49.20.6.

definition: ἑλίκωψ, ωπος, ὁ, ἡ, fem. ἑλῐκ-ῶπις, ιδος,

children.definition: with rolling eyes, quick-glancing, as a mark of youth and spirits (not in Od.), ἑλίκωπες Ἀχαιοί Il. 1.389, al.; ἑλικῶπις κούρη ib. 98; νύμφη Hes. Th. 298, cf. Sapph. 44.5 L.-P.; παρθένοι, Ἀφροδίτη, Pi. Pae. 2.99, P. 6.1.
vine-tendril, Philet. ap. EM 330.39.
the vine, Nic. Al. 181, Opp. C. 4.262, D.P. 1157. [Later ἕλινος prob. in Nonn. D. 12.299.]
like vine-tendrils, Hymn.Is. 18.
bearing vine-tendrils, κόρυμβος Nonn. D. 16.278; Διόνυσος ib. 17.333.
days of rest, holidays: ἐλινύας ἄγειν, of the Roman supplication, Plb. 21.2.1.

definition: Ἐλινύμενος, title of Zeus at Cyrene, Hsch.

ἐλινύω, Hdt. 1.67, Hp. Acut. 47, A. Pr. 53: impf. ἐλίνυον Hdt. 8.71, ἠλ- App. Mith. 43; Ion. ἐλινύεσκον A.R. 1.589: fut. -ύσω [ῡ] Pi. N. 5.1, I. 2.46: aor. ἐλίνῡσα Hdt. 7.56, A. Pr. 529 (lyr.), etc.:—

children.definition: Ion. Verb, also used in Trag. and late Prose (as Plu. Num. 14), keep holiday, take rest, repose, freq. in Hp., as Acut. 47; μὴ ἐλινύειν Hdt. 1.67; διέβη ὁ στρατὸς . . ἐλινύσας οὐδένα χρόνον without any cessation, Id. 7.56; ἐλινύσοντα . . ἀγάλματα to stand unmoved on their pedestals, Pi. N. 5.1, cf. I. 2.46; ὡς μή σʼ ἐλινύοντα προσδερχθῇ πατήρ see thee standing idle, A. Pr. 53; οὐκ ἐλινύειν ἐχρῆν Ar. Th. 598; ἐ. μίαν ἡμέραν Orac. ap. D. 21.53.
rest from, πλήθεος βρώμης Hp. Acut. 47 (v.l.< ἐκ>) ; ἔργων D.H. 1.33.

part., rest or cease from doing, ἐλίνυον οὐδένα χρόνον . . ἐργαζόμενοι Hdt. 8.71, cf. A. Pr. 529 (lyr.), Call. Cer. 48, Fr. 248. [ υ of the impf. short in A.R. 1.862, long ib. 589, indeterminate in Trag.] (Written ἐλιννύω in some codd.)

definition: ἕλιξ (A), ῐκος, ὁ, ἡ, as Adj.,

children.definition: twisted, curved: in Hom. and Hes., as in S. Aj. 374 (lyr.), Theoc. 25.127, epith. of oxen, commonly understood of their twisted, crumpled horns, cf. ἑλικτός I; also expld. of the movement of their bodies as they walk, rolling: freq. coupled with εἰλίπους, cf. Il. 12.293 and Sch. ad loc., etc.; ἕλιξ abs., = βοῦς, E. Ba. 1170 (lyr.): later of various objects, ποταμός Pi. ap. Sch. Il. Oxy. 221 ix 15; ἕλικα ἀνὰ χλόαν on the tangled grass, E. Hel. 180 (lyr., cf. sq. [ἕλιξ] III); δρόμος Nonn. D. 2.263; σειρή Tryph. 322.

definition: ἕλιξ (B), poet. εἷλιξ, ῐκος, ἡ, ( ἑλίσσω)

children.definition: anything which assumes a spiral shape: once in Hom., γναμπτάς θʼ ἕλικας, of armlets or ear-rings, Il. 18.401 (cf. ἑλικτήρ), cf. h.Ven. 87, Arist. Mir. 840b20:—afterwards in various relations:

children.label: II
children.definition: whirl, convolution, ἕλικες στεροπῆς flashes of forked lightning, A. Pr. 1083 (anap.); of circular or spiral motion, αἱ κινήσεις καὶ ἕλικες τοῦ οὐρανοῦ Arist. Metaph. 998a5; ἕλικα ἐκτυλίσσειν Ti.Locr. 97c; wreath of smoke, A.R. 1.438.

data.quote: αἱ κινήσεις καὶ ἕλικες τοῦ οὐρανοῦ

children.label: III
children.definition: tendril of the vine, Thphr. CP 2.18.2; βοσκὰς εὐφύλλων ἑλίκων E. Hel. 1331 (lyr.); βότρυος ἕλικα παυσίπονον the clustering grape, Ar. Ra. 1321 (lyr.).
tendril of ivy, Id. Th. 1000; also, ivy, Hedera Helix, Thphr. HP 3.18.6, 7.8.1.
curl or lock of hair, AP 10.19 ( Apollonid.), 12.10 ( Strat.), Anacreont. 16.6.
coil of a serpent, E. HF 399 (lyr.): pl., feelers of the polypus, AP 9.14 ( Antiphil. Byz.).
volute on the capital of a column, Callix. 1, Vitr. 4.1.12.

children.label: IV
children.definition: convolution of a spiral shell (cf. ἑλίκη II), Arist. HA 547b11: pl., convolutions of the bowels, Id. PA 675b24: sg., colon, ib. 675b20; also of the ear, Id. de An. 420a13, Ruf. Onom. 44.

children.label: V
children.definition: spiral running round a staff, Ael. VH 9.11, Ath. 12.543f; on a childʼs ball, A.R. 3.139; spiral strip folded round the scytale, Plu. Lys. 19.
spiral, Epicur. Ep. 2p.40U., Hermesian. 7.86; περὶ ἑλίκων, title of work by Archim.; also, = κύκλος, Hsch.

children.label: b
children.definition: orbit, Eudox. Ars 5.3, Theo Sm. p.201 H.; but also of the sunʼs and moonʼs orbits, Eudox. Ars 9.2.
helix, screw-windlass, employed in launching ships, invented by Archimedes, Moschio ap. Ath. 5.207b.
treadmill used to raise water, Ph. 1.410.

children.label: VI
children.definition: involved sentences, D.H. Th. 48.

children.label: VII
children.definition: Adj. winding, ὁ ῥοῦς φέρεται ἕλικα πορείαν Dion.Byz. 3.
rolled bandage, Hp. Off. 10.
convolution of the bowels, Aret. SA 2.6.
with crumpled horns, κριός AP 9.240 ( Phil.).
revolving, ἄτρακτος Procl. H. 1.48.

definition: ἑλίσσω or ἐλίσσω (the latter more freq. in codd. of Hom.), Att. ἑλίττω, Ep. inf. -έμεν Il. 23.309; Ion. εἰλίσσω or εἱλίσσω ( εἱ. is found in codd. of Hdt. (v. infr.), but κατ-ελίσσειν Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 37 (14), κατειλίξαι Id. Morb. 2.18, al.): fut. ἑλίξω E. Ph. 711: aor. εἴλιξα Pl. Ti. 73a ( εἵλ- codd., but κατ-ειλίξας IG 2(2).204.32); part. ἑλίξας Il. 23.466, Ion. εἰλίξας Hdt. 4.34:— Med., Il. 23.320: fut. ἑλίξομαι 17.728: aor. ἑλιξάμην 12.467, 17.283:— Pass., fut. ἑλιγήσομαι LXX Is. 34.4: aor.1 εἱλίχθην E. Or. 358; part. ἑλιχθείς Il. 12.74: pf. εἵλιγμαι Hes. Th. 791, ἐλήλιγμαι Paus. 10.17.12: plpf. εἵλικτο E. HF 927; Ion. 3 pl. εἱλίχατο Hdt. 7.90. —The Ion. form is found in Trag. (v. infr., codd. usu. εἱλ-; but τʼ εἰ. A. Pr. 138 (lyr., cod. Med.), cf. Ar. Ra. 1314, 1348 (cod. Rav.)), in IG l.c., and codd. of Pl. (as Ti. l.c., ἀν-ειλίττων Phlb. 15e); ἐπειλίξας is f.l. in D. 23.161. ( ϝελ-, ἐϝελ-, cf. εἴλω, ἐλελίζω ad fin.):—

children.definition: turn round or about: Act. in Hom. always of turning a chariot round the doubling-post, οἶσθα γὰρ εὖ περὶ τέρματʼ ἐλισσέμεν [ἵππους] Il. 23.309, cf. 466.

roll, ἑ. βίου πόρον roll lifeʼs stream along, Pi. I. 8(7).15; of the chariot of Day, αἰθὴρ κοινὸν φάος εἱλίσσων A. Pr. 1092 (anap.); ἥλιος . . εἱλίσσων φλόγα E. Ph. 3; εἰ. κόνιν roll the eddying dust, A. Pr. 1085 (anap.); ἑ. δίνας, of the Euripus, E. IT 7, cf. 1103 (lyr.); ἑ. κόρας, βλέφαρα, Id. HF 868 (troch.), Or. 1266 (lyr.).

ἅλιον . . ἑ. πλάταν ply it swiftly, S. Aj. 358 (lyr.); of the dance, ἑ. πόδα move the swift foot, cj. in E. Or. 171 (lyr.), cf. IA 215 (lyr.); εἱ. θιάσους lead the dancing bands, Id. IT 1145 (lyr.); ἑ. χορούς Stratt. 66.5: abs., dance, E. Ph. 234 (lyr.), cf. Or. 1292 (whence ἑ. τινά dance in honour of . ., Id. HF 690 (lyr.), IA 1480 (lyr.)); ἑ. βωμόν dance round it, Call. Del. 321.
roll or wind round, πλόκαμον περὶ ἄτρακτον Hdt. 4.34, cf. 2.38; λίνον ἠλακάτᾳ δακτύλοις ἑ. E. Or. 1432 (lyr.); χεῖρας ἀμφὶ γόνυ ἑ. clasp them round . ., Id. Ph. 1622.
turn in oneʼs mind, revolve, τοιαῦθʼ ἑ. S. Ant. 231, cf. Pl. Epin. 978d; μῆτιν A.R. 1.463; ἑ. κακοὺς λόγους speak wily words, E. Or. 892.
κόλπους ἑ. form winding reaches, of rivers, D.P. 630; ἀγκῶνας Id. 979.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med. and Pass., turn oneself round or about (but in Il. 12.49 εἱλίσσεθʼ ἑταίρους (as read by Nicanor) rallied his comrades), ἑλιχθέντων ὑπʼ Ἀχαιῶν when they turned to face the foe, ib. 74, cf. 408; so of a wild boar, ἑλιξάμενος having turned to bay, 17.283; of a serpent, coil himself, ἑλισσόμενος περὶ χειῇ 22.95; ἡ δέ τʼ ἐλισσομένη πέτεται (sc. καλαῦροψ) the shepherdʼs staff flies spinning through the air, 23.846; κνίση . . ἑλισσομένη περὶ καπνῷ rolling with the smoke, 1.317; ἑλισσόμενοι περὶ δίνας whirled round in the eddies, 21.11; of a river, δίνῃς ἀργυρέῃς εἱλιγμένος Hes. Th. 791, cf. D.S. 1.32; of the waves, τὸ ἑλισσόμενον αἰεὶ κυμάτων Pi. N. 6.55; of ocean, ἑλίσσεσθαι περὶ πᾶσαν χθόνα A. Pr. 138; ὧραι ἑλισσόμεναι the circling hours, Pi. O. 4.3.
turn hither and thither, go about, ἀνʼ ὅμιλον Il. 12.49; καθʼ ὅμιλον ib. 467; ἑλίσσετο ἔνθα καὶ ἔνθα turned himself hither and thither, doubting what to do, Od. 20.24.
to be constantly in or about a thing, περὶ φύσας Il. 18.372; ἔν τινι, εἴς τι, Pl. Tht. 194b, Porph. ap. Eus. PE 3.4: c. gen., μέλιτός τε καὶ ἔργων εἱλίσσονται (sc. μέλισσαι) Arat. 1030.
whirl in the dance, E. Ba. 569 (lyr.), IA 1055 (lyr.).
Med. in act. sense, ἧκε δέ μιν σφαιρηδὸν ἑλιξάμενος he threw it with a whirl like a ball, Il. 13.204.
τὰς κεφαλὰς εἱλίχατο μίτρῃσι have their heads rolled round with turbans, Hdt. 7.90.
whirling the wheel round, σύριγγες ἑ. A. Th. 205 (lyr.).
gold-flower, Helichrysum siculum, Alcm. 16, Ibyc. 6, Cratin. 98; ξανθοτέρα ἑλιχρύσοιο Theoc. 2.78.
funnel in an oil-press, CPR 242i10 (i A.D.).
fester, A. Ch. 843.
wound, Hsch., who also has ἑλκανῶσα, = ἑλκαίνουσα.

definition: ἑλκείδιον, τό, Dim. of ἕλκος, Plu. Aet.Gr. 300a (s.v.l.).

children.definition: trailing the robe, with long train, Il. 6.442, al., Mus. 286, Nonn. D. 1.103.
drawing the hand after it, τρύπανα AP 6.103 ( Phil.).
cloak-trailer, nickname of a Laconian, Pl. Com. 124.
trailing the tunic, with a long tunic, epith. of the Ionians, Il. 13.685, h.Ap. 147.

drag about, tear asunder, in impf. νέκυν . . εἵλκεον ἀμφότεροι Il. 17.395: also in fut. and aor. κύνες ἑλκήσουσιν ib. 558; σὲ μὲν κύνες ἠδʼ οἰωνοὶ ἑλκήσουσʼ 22.336; Λητὼ γὰρ ἥλκησε he did violence to Leto, Od. 11.580; ἑ. τινὰ πέπλοιο Arat. 638:— Pass., ἑλκηθείσας τε θύγατρας Il. 22.62.

data.quote: σὲ μὲν κύνες ἠδʼ οἰωνοὶ ἑλκήσουσʼ

children.definition: by dragging, pulling, ἐμάχοντο πύξ τε καὶ ἑλκηδόν Hes. Sc. 302.
full of ulcers, Man. 1.162.
being carried off, violence suffered, σῆς τε βοῆς σοῦ θʼ ἑλκηθμοῖο πυθέσθαι Il. 6.465.

data.quote: σῆς τε βοῆς σοῦ θʼ ἑλκηθμοῖο πυθέσθαι

children.definition: stock of the plough, Thphr. HP 5.7.6.
that which is torn in pieces, prey, κυνῶν ἕ. E. HF 568.
drawing the ears of corn, νομῆες Orac. ap. Paus. 8.42.

definition: ἑλκητήρ, ῆρος, ὁ, one that drags, κτένες ἑλκητῆρες, of a harrow, AP 6.297 ( Phan.). -->
ἕλκιμος, ον, = ἑλκύσιμος, Olymp. in Mete. 320.37.

children.definition: make wounds or sores: metaph., rip up old sores, Aeschin. 3.208.

children.label: II
children.definition: make an incision in a tree, πρέμνον Gp. 5.38.

definition: ἑλκοποιός, όν, having power to wound, A. Th. 398; cf. ἑλκοποιόν· κανθαρίς, Hsch. -->

children.definition: wound, Il. 4.190, al. (never in Od.), Pi. P. 2.91, E. Tr. 1232 (pl.), etc.

festering wound, sore, ulcer, ἕ. ὕδρου the festering bite of a serpent, Il. 2.723; plague-ulcer, Th. 2.49, X. Eq. 5.1, etc. ( Gal. 10.232 defines ἕ. as ἡ τῆς συνεχείας λύσις ἐν σαρκώδει μορίῳ, and both 1.1 and 1.2 are treated in Hp. Ulc.; ἕ. is applied to amputations in Art. 68.)

children.label: II
children.definition: wound, loss, Sol. 4.17, S. Ant. 652, al.; ἕ. δήμιον A. Ag. 640; ὑποκάρδιον ἕ. Theoc. 11.15; γίγνεται ἕ. ἐφʼ ἕλκει Lib. Ep. 1063.6. (Orig. ἔλκος, cf. Lat. ulcus, Skt. árśas (n.) ‘haemorrhoidʼ: ἕ- by influence of ἕλκω.)
wound, lacerate, E. Hec. 405; ἑ. ὄνυξιν Arist. HA 630a5, etc.
ulcerate, βλέφαρα Hp. VM 19, al.:— Pass., of persons, to suffer from wounds or sores, Com.Adesp. 106.8, Ev.Luc. 16.20; of sores, suppurate, X. Eq. 1.5.
make an incision in a tree, Thphr. HP 4.16.1 ( Pass.), CP 3.2.2 ( Pass.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑ. φρένας, οἴκους, E. Alc. 878 (lyr.), Supp. 223:— Pass., τὴν διάνοιαν ἑλκοῦσθαι Ph. 2.551.
one must drag, Pl. R. 365c.
fit for drawing, attractive, πρός τι Pl. R. 523a, cf. Thphr. CP 3.17.3 ( Comp.), Ael. NA 17.6.
that can be drawn, tensile, Arist. GA 743b5, Mete. 385a16.
Dim. of ἕλκος, slight sore, Hp. Art. 63, Ar. Eq. 907.

children.label: II
children.definition: Dionys.Trag. 12.

definition: ἑλκυθμός, ὁ, later form of ἑλκηθμός, Tryph. 21.

children.definition: that may be drawn, Phot. s.v. ἐρύσιμον.
attraction, πύου Aret. SD 1.10.
drawing, ἕ. τῆς σικύης, in cupping, Hp. Loc.Hom. 22.
that which is drawn, i.e. spun wool, Hsch. s.v. ἀφρῖνον (pl.).
κυνῶν ἑ. bodies torn by dogs, Man. 4.200.
dross of silver, because drawn off with a hook, Dsc. 5.86, Gal. 12.236, Orib. Fr. 90.
attraction; esp. of idle fancy, διάκενος ἑ. Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.22, cf. Ph. 1.151 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: dragging, in pl., Anon. Fig. p.156 S.
drag about, ἵνα μή μιν ἀποδρύφοι ἑλκυστάζων Il. 23.187, 24.21.
to be dragged, X. Ages. 9.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑλκυστέον one must draw, αἷμα Gal. ap. Aët. 8.50.
one must drink, οὐκ ἀθρόον πόμα Herod.Med. ib. 4.47.
instrument for drawing: surgeonʼs crochet, Hp. Mul. 1.70; a rein, Sch. Il. 16.475, Hsch. s.v. ῥυτήρ.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., ἑ. πόνος toil of dragging, Opp. H. 5.20.
fit for drawing, ζῷα draught animals, Men.Prot. p.17 D.
drawing: extracting, c. gen., σκολόπων Dsc. 2.84.
attractive, ἑ. τι ἔχειν πρὸς φιλίαν Ath. 5.185c; τὰ πιθανὰ καὶ ἑ. Arr. Epict. 3.12.14.
ductile, Hsch. s.v. ῥύσιον, Gloss.
drawn, ἑ. ἅμαξα transport-wagon, PMasp. 303.7 ( vi A.D., -ιστή Pap.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑ. ἔλαιον refined, fine-drawn oil, CIG 2719.21 ( Stratonicea); cf. ἑλκυστῷ· λείῳ, Hsch.
handle or lever for raising a swing-beam, Apollod. Poliorc. 162.10.
halter, Hsch. s.v. φορβε<ί>α.

definition: ἕλκω ( ἑλκύω late, Tz. H. 6.621), Il. 24.52, etc., impf. εἷλκον A. Fr. 39, etc., Ep. ἕλκον Il. 4.213, al. (never εἵλκυον): fut. ἕλξω A. Supp. 909, etc., rarely ἑλκύσω [ῠ] Hp. Fract. 2, Philem. 174: aor. εἵλκῠσα Batr. 232, Pi. N. 7.103, Trag. and Att., E. Ph. 987, Ar. Nu. 540, SIG 2587.23, al., etc.; ἥλκυσα IG ΙΙ(2).287 B 61 ( Delos, ii B.C.), CIG 4993,5006 ( Egypt, iii A.D.); later εἷλξα, poet. ἕλξα AP 9.370 ( Tib. Ill.), Orph. A. 258, Gal. Nat.Fac. 1.12: pf. εἵλκῠκα D. 22.59; pf. part. ἑολκώς prob. in Epich. 177:— Med., fut. -ύσομαι ( ἐφ-) Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.10.9: aor. εἱλκυσάμην ( ἀφ-) v.l. in Hp. Art. 11, subj. ἀφελκύσωμαι Ar. Ach. 1120; rarely εἱλξάμην Gal. 4.534:— Pass., fut. ἑλκυσθήσομαι A. Th. 614 ( ξυγκαθ-), Lyc. 358, ἑλχθήσομαι Gal. UP 7.7: aor. εἱλκύσθην Hp. Epid. 4.14, ( ἐξ-) Ar. Ec. 688, ἑλκ- Hdt. 1.140, ἡλκ- IG 12(7).115.11 ( Amorgos); later εἵλχθην Ph. 2.11, Philostr. VA 8.15, D.L. 6.91: pf. εἵλκυσμαι Hp. Superf. 16, E. Rh. 576, Ph. 1.316, ( καθ-) Th. 6.50, ἕλκυσμαι ( ἀν-) Hdt. 9.98, ἥλκυσμαι BGU 1256.11 (ii B.C.): plpf. εἵλκυστο Hp. Epid. 4.36.—In Att., ἕλκω, ἕλξω were alone used in pres. and fut., while the other tenses were formed from ἑλκυ-; cf. ἑλκέω (q.v.), ἑλκυστάζω. In Hom., Aristarch. rejected the augm. (Cf. Lat. sulcus, Lith. velkù ‘dragʼ):—

children.definition: draw, drag, with collat.notion of force or exertion, ὣς εἰπὼν ποδὸς ἕλκε began to drag [the dead body] by the foot, Il. 13.383; ἤν περ . . ποδῶν ἕλκωσι θύραζε Od. 16.276; τινὰ τῆς ῥινός Luc. Herm. 73; Ἕκτορα . . περὶ σῆμʼ ἑτάροιο ἕλκει Il. 24.52; drag away a prisoner, 22.65 ( Pass.); draw ships down to the sea, 2.152, etc.; draw along a felled tree, 17.743; of mules, draw a chariot, 24.324; ἑλκέμεναι νειοῖο . . πηκτὸν ἄροτρον draw the plough through the field, 10.353, cf. 23.518; ἕ. τινὰ ἐπὶ κνάφου Hdt. 1.92; περιβαλόντας σχοινία ἕ. haul at them, Id. 5.85.

draw after one, ἐν δʼ ἔπεσʼ Ὠκεανῷ . . φάος ἠελίοιο, ἕλκον νύκτα μέλαιναν Il. 8.486; πέδας ἕ. trail fetters after one, Hdt. 3.129; ἕ. χλανίδα let oneʼs cloak trail behind, Ephipp. 19 (anap.); θοἰμάτιον Archipp. 45.

data.quote: ἐν δʼ ἔπεσʼ Ὠκεανῷ . . φάος ἠελίοιο, ἕλκον νύκτα μέλαιναν

children.definition: tear in pieces (used by Hom. only in the form ἑλκέω) , ὀνύχεσσι παρειάν E. Tr. 280; worry, τὰς κύνας ὥλαφος ἕλκοι Theoc. 1.135; ἑλκυσθῆναι ὑπὸ κυνός Hdt. 1.140.

children.label: b
children.definition: carp at, Pi. N. 7.103.
draw a bow, ἕλκε . . γλυφίδας τε λαβὼν καὶ νεῦρα βόεια Il. 4.122, cf. Od. 21.419, Hdt. 3.21, X. An. 4.2.28, etc.

data.quote: ἕλκε . . γλυφίδας τε λαβὼν καὶ νεῦρα βόεια

children.definition: draw a sword, S. Ant. 1233, E. Rh. 576 ( Pass.):— Med., ἕλκετο δʼ ἐκ κολεοῖο . . ξίφος Il. 1.194.
ἕ. ἱστία hoist sails, Od. 2.426:—also in Med., h.Bacch. 32.
lift up scales, so as to poise them, ἕλκε δὲ μέσσα λαβών Il. 8.72, 22.212.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hom.,
pull a barge-pole, Hdt. 1.194.
tow a ship, Th. 2.90, etc.

drag into court, ἕλκω σε κλητεύσοντα Ar. Nu. 1218, cf. 1004 ( Pass.); εἰς ἀγοράν Act.Ap. 16.19; drag about, esp. with lewd violence, ἕλκει καὶ βιάζεται D. 21.150; μηδένα ἕλξειν μηδʼ ὑβριεῖν ib. 221; ἕλκειν γυναῖκα Lys. 1.12: metaph., ἄνω κάτω τοὺς λόγους ἕ. Pl. Tht. 195c, cf. Arist. SE 167a35; ἡμέας ὁ καιρὸς ἕλκει Herod. 2.10; also ἥλκυσμαι λαμπαδάρχης I have been compelled to serve as λ., BGU l.c.

draw or suck up, [ ἥλιος] ἕλκει τὸ ὕδωρ ἐπʼ ἑωυτόν Hdt. 2.25; ἕ. τὸν ἀέρα draw it in, breathe it, Hp. Aër. 19, Ti.Locr. 101d ( Pass.), cf. Philyll. 20: ζωὴν φύσιν Archel. ap. Antig. Mir. 89; esp. of persons drinking, drink in long draughts, quaff, μέθυ E. Ion 1200; ἄμυστιν Id. Cyc. 417; τὴν . . τοῦ Πραμνίου [σπονδήν] Ar. Eq. 107; οἶνον ἐκ . . λεπαστῆς Telecl. 24 (lyr.); ἀπνευστί Antiph. 74.14, etc.: with acc. of the cup, δέπας μεστὸν . . ἕλκουσι γνάθοις ἀπαύστοις Id. 237, cf. Eub. 56.7, al.; so ἕ. μαστόν suck it, E. Ph. 987; inhale, ὀσμήν Antig. Mir. 89; of roots, draw up nourishment, Thphr. HP 1.6.10: metaph., χανδὸν καὶ ἀμυστὶ τῶν μαθηυάτων ἕ. Eun. VS p.474D.

data.quote: ἥλιος] ἕλκει τὸ ὕδωρ ἐπʼ ἑωυτόν

children.definition: draw from a receptacle, ἐξ ἑκάστου κιβωτίου πινάκιον ἕν Arist. Ath. 64.1.

ἕ. βίοτον, ζόαν, drag out a weary life, E. Or. 207 (lyr.), Ph. 1535 (lyr.); προφάσιας ἕ. keep making excuses, Hdt. 6.86; πάσας τε προφάσεις . . ἕλκουσι Ar. Lys. 727; ἕ. χρόνους make long, in prosody, Longin. Proll. Heph. p.83C.: hence intr., ἐπὶ τοσοῦτο λέγεται ἑλκύσαι τὴν σύστασιν . . that the conflict dragged on, lasted, Hdt. 7.167, cf. PHib. 1.83.9 (iii B.C.):— Pass., τῶν ἐγκλημάτων εἱκλυσμένων πλείονα χρόνον Supp.Epigr. 2.281 ( Delph., ii B.C.); also of a person, ἑλκόμενος καὶ μόγις Pl. R. 350d.
ἕ. κόρδακα dance in long, measured steps, Ar. Nu. 540; ἓν τουτὶ ( σχῆμα) Id. Pax 328.

draw to oneself, attract, of the magnet, E. Fr. 567; by spells, τινὰ ποτὶ δῶμα Theoc. 2.17, cf. X. Mem. 3.11.18, Plot. 4.4.40, etc.; πείθειν καὶ ἑ. Pl. R. 458d; ἐχθροὺς ἐφʼ ἑαυτόν D. 22.59; draw on, ἐπὶ ἡδονάς Pl. Phdr. 238a; εἰς τυραννίδας ἕ. τὰς πολιτείας Id. R. 568c:— Pass., to be drawn on as by a spell, ἴυγγι δʼ ἕλκομαι ἦτορ Pi. N. 4.35; πρὸς φιλοσοφίαν Pl. R. 494e.
ἕ. σταθμὸν τάλαντα δέκα draw down the balance, i.e. weigh ten talents, Hdt. 1.50, cf. Eup. 116: abs., τὸ δʼ ἂν ἑλκύσῃ whatever it weigh, Hdt. 2.65; πλεῖον ἕ. Pl. Min. 316a.

children.label: b
children.definition: ἕ. τὰς ψήφους cast up the account, PPetr. 2p.37 (iii B.C.), PHib. 1.17.25 (iii B.C.).

draw or derive from a source, ἐντεῦθεν εἵλκυσεν ἐπὶ τὴν . . τέχνην τὸ πρός φορον αὐτῇ Pl. Phdr. 270a, cf. Jul. Or. 7.207a; τὸ γένος ἀπό τινος Str. 11.9.3; assume, μείζω φαντασίαν Plb. 32.10.5; ὁ ἄρτος ἕλκει χρῶμα κάλλιστον Ath. 3.113c.

data.quote: ἐντεῦθεν εἵλκυσεν ἐπὶ τὴν . . τέχνην τὸ πρός φορον αὐτῇ

children.definition: ἑλκύσαι πλίνθους make bricks, Hdt. 1.179, cf. PPetr. 3p.137; ἕ. λάγανον Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 14.647e.
αἱ θυρίδες ἕλκουσι the windows draw in air, Thphr. Vent. 29.
ἕ. ἑαυτόν, expressing some kind of athletic exercise, Pl. Prm. 135d.

children.label: B
children.definition: Med., ἕ. χαίτας ἐκ κεφαλῆς tear oneʼs hair, Il. 10.15; ἀσσοτέρω πυρὸς ἕλκετο δίφρον drew his chair nearer to the fire, Od. 19.506, cf. Semon. 7.26.
draw to oneself, scrape up, amass, τιμάς, ἄφενος ἕλκεσθαι, Thgn. 30.
ἕλκεσθαι στάθμας περισσᾶς in Pi. P. 2.90, means lit., to drag at too great a line, i.e. grasp more than oneʼs due-- but whence the metaphor is taken remains unexplained.

children.label: C
children.definition: Pass., to be drawn or wrenched, νῶτα . . ἑλκόμενα στερεῶς, of wrestlers, Il. 23.715; of the nails, to be curved, Hp. Morb. 2.48; to close in when the core is removed, of the timber of certain trees, Thphr. HP 5.5.2.
to be drawn or to flow at a place, of streams, Lyc. 702; πρὸς ἀντολίην ἕ. αἶα D.P. 1086.
to be drawn or contracted, εἱλκύσθη ἐπὶ τὰ δεξιὰ τράχηλος Hp. Epid. 4.14.
like a wound or sore, ulcerated, στόματα Hp. Epid. 3.7; χρώς E. Hipp. 1359 (anap.); κνῆμαι Arist. Pr. 895a31.
causing or accompanied by soreness, ἁφή S.E. M. 7.179; κόπος Gal. 7.179; πόνος Archig. ap. eund. 8.106; κονιορτός Lyd. Ost. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: irritable, Plb. 32.11.8; θυμός Plu. Cohib. 2.454b.
sore, ulcer, Hp. Epid. 3.7, POxy. 1088.2, 9 (i A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: part wounded, Thphr. HP 9.2.1.
causing sores, ulcerating, Dsc. 5.91.
ulceration, Hp. Aph. 3.21, Th. 2.49, Ph. 2.1co; of plants, Thphr. CP 1.14.2, al.

definition: ἑλκωτικός, ή, όν, = ἑλκωματικός, Dsc. 1.128.3: metaph.,

children.definition: exasperating, δριμύτης Plu. Comp. Arist. Men. 2.854c.

definition: ἑλλά, ἡ, Lacon. for καθέδρα, Hsch.:—also Ἕλλα· Διὸς ἱερὸν ἐν Δωδώνῃ, Id.

children.definition: hold office of Ἑλλαδάρχης 3>, IGRom. 3.202 ( Ancyra, ii A.D.).
president of the κοινὸν τῶν Ἀχαιῶν, IG 4.1600 ( Corinth, ii A.D.), SIG 846.5 ( Delph., ii A.D.).
official of the Delphic Amphictyony, Ἑ. ἀμφικτυόνων IG 4.590 ( Argos, ii A.D.).
official of the Greek community in the province of Galatia, IGRom. 3.211 ( Ancyra, ii A.D.).
OGI 528.10 ( Prusias).
Hellenic, ἀοιδαί Xenoph. 6; κλίμα Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.45; [ ἵπποι] Str. 11.13.7; οἱ Ἑ. Plu. QConv. 2.676b.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑλλαδική, ἡ, name of a plaster, Alex.Trall. 9.1; Ἑλλαδικὸν μάλαγμα Aet. 15.11.

definition: ἔλλαθι, = ἵληθι, B. 10.8; Aeol. for ἵλαθι, Et.Gud. s.v. χίλιοι: pl., ἔλλατε Call. Fr. 121.

children.definition: talk amongst, μειρακίοις Pherecr. 64 (prob.).
receive, Supp.Epigr. 2.264.6 ( Delph., ii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., aor. 2 ἐνελαβόμην IG 12(5).1061.10 ( Carthaea):— seize hold of, τῶν δένδρων ταῖς ἕλιξι Dsc. 4.183, cf. Ph. 1.21, al., J. AJ 6.7.5, etc.
gain distinction, ἰδίᾳ ἐ. τῷ τῆς πόλεως κινδύνῳ Th. 6.12; pride oneself, Luc. Dom. 1; ἔργῳ D.C. 73.10; ἱππεῦσιν App. BC 3.66; πρὸς τὰς φίλας ἐ. λόγοις J. AJ 18.3.4.

data.quote: ἰδίᾳ ἐ. τῷ τῆς πόλεως κινδύνῳ

children.definition: shine, Σείριος . . ὀξὺς ἐ. Archil. 61: c. dat., shine upon, irradiate, τῇ ψυχῇ Ph. 1.273; πᾶσιν Procl. Inst. 23; εἰς ψυχήν Hierocl. in CA 10p.433M.; εἰς τὴν οἰκείαν ἕδραν Jul. Or. 4.134b; shine or be reflected in, ἐν τοῖς ὄμμασι τῶν πλησίον Plu. Aud. 2.40d: c. dat., Iamb. Myst. 2.3, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: illuminate, ἐλλάμπουσα ἀεὶ ἐλλάμπεται Plot. 2.9.2, cf. Procl. in Ti. 2.285 D., al.; ὅταν [ἡ ψυχὴ] οἷον ἐλλάμψῃ πρὸς ἑαυτήν Plot. 6.4.16:—metaph. in Med., distinguish oneself, gain glory in or with, [ τῷ ἱππικῷ] ἐπεῖχε ἐλλάμψεσθαι Hdt. 1.80; τῇσι νηυσί Id. 8.74.

data.quote: ὅταν [ἡ ψυχὴ] οἷον ἐλλάμψῃ πρὸς ἑαυτήν

children.definition: cause to shine upon, καλλονὴν ἑκάστῳ Them. Or. 4.52b; cause to shine, ἡ τῶν θεῶν παρουσία τὸ φῶς ἐ. Iamb. Myst. 2.6.
shining, flashing, Placit. 3.3.12 (v.l.), Plu. Fr.inc. 150: metaph., illumination, irradiation, Plot. 6.4.15, 5.8, al., Dam. Pr. 34; τῆς ἀληθείας Hierocl. in CA 20p.465M.

children.label: II
children.definition: radiation of heat, Steph. in Hp. 1.134 D., al.
the chief judges at the Olympic games, Pi. O. 3.12 (sg.), Hellanic. 113J. (sg.), Paus. 5.9.5 sq.; also, at the Nemean games, IG 4.587 ( Argos); at Epidaurus, ib. 946 (iii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: court-martial to try cases arising among the allied troops, X. Lac. 13.11.—The Dor. form (Elean Ἑλλανοζίκας Schwyzer 409) is used in Att., but Ἑλληνοδίκαι is found in SIG 1073.20, and is v.l. in Hdt. 5.22, cf. Hsch. s.v. et s.v. Δίαρχοι.
to be a judge at the games, Paus. 6.1.5, 24.3.
the place where the Ἑλλανοδίκαι held their meetings, Paus. 6.24.1.
Hellas, said to have been originally the name of the region round Dodona, Arist. Mete. 352a34, Sch. Il. 21.194.
οἵ τʼ εἶχον Φθίην ἠδʼ Ἑλλάδα Il. 2.683.

data.quote: οἵ τʼ εἶχον Φθίην ἠδʼ Ἑλλάδα

children.definition: part of Phthiotis, inhabited by the Μυρμιδόνες, 9.395, al.
Northern Greece, opp. Peloponnesus, D. 19.303, Ptol. Geog. 3.14.1: sts. so expld. in the phrase καθʼ Ἑλλάδα καὶ μέσον Ἄργος Od. 1.344, 4.726, al.
Greece, from Peloponnesus to Epirus and Thessaly inclusively, Hes. Op. 653, Hdt. 8.44, 47, A. Pers. 50 (anap.), 234 (troch.): used collectively for Ἕλληνες, E. Or. 648, Th. 1.6, etc.

all lands inhabited by Hellenes, including Ionia, etc., Hdt. 1.92, Th. 1.3, X. An. 6.5.23, etc.; οὔθʼ Ἑ. οὔτʼ ἄγλωσσος S. Tr. 1060: hence ἡ ἀρχαία Ἑ. Old Greece, Plu. Tim. 37; ἡ μεγάλη Ἑ. Magna Graecia, Plb. 2.39.1, Ath. 12.523e; including Sicily, Str. 6.1.2.
Ἑλλάδος Ἑ., Ἀθῆναι AP 7.45 (Thuc.): pl., τὴν Ἑ. Ἑλλάσι πολλαῖς παραυξήσας Ph. 2.567.
φωνή) the Greek language, Ael. VH 9.16.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. Greek, γλῶσσα Hdt. 6.98, al.; πόλις Id. 5.93; χθών A. Supp. 243; στολή S. Ph. 223, etc.; masc., Id. Fr. 17; τίς Ἑ. ἢ βάρβαρος ἢ τῶν προπάροιθʼ εὐγενετᾶν ἕτερος . . ; E. Ph. 1509.
need hellebore, i.e. to be mad, Call.Com. 28.

definition: ἑλλεβορίζω, Ion. ἐλλ-, fut. -ιῶ Hp. Ep. 20:—

children.definition: dose with hellebore, Id. Mochl. 30, Plu. Alex. 41, Archig. ap. Orib. 8.1.1 ( Pass.), etc.; and so, to bring one to his senses, τί σαυτὸν οὐχ ἑλλεβορίζεις; D. 18.121: -όμενοι, title of play by Diph., AB 100.
rupture-wort, Herniaria glabra, Thphr. HP 9.10.2, Dsc. 4.108.
treatment with hellebore, Hp. Ep. 21.
flavoured with hellebore, Dsc. 5.72.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑλλεβορ-ίτης, ου, ὁ, = κενταύρειον μικρόν, Ps.- Dsc. 3.7.
who prescribes hellebore, Gal. Thras. 24.
drinking of hellebore, Hp. Epid. 5.83.

hellebore, Hp. Acut. 23, Aph. 4.13, Thphr. HP 9.10.1, etc. ( ἑ. λευκός white hellebore, Veratrum album, Dsc. 4.148; ἑ. μέλας hellebore, Helleborus orientalis (or cyclophyllus), ib. 162); given to the insane, Hp. Vict. 1.35: hence, πῖθʼ ἑλλέβορον, i.e. you are mad, Ar. V. 1489; ἑλλέβορον ἤδη πώποτʼ ἔπιες; Men. 69 (prob.l.); ἐλλέβορον πῖσαι Hp. Fract. 11, cf. Str. 9.3.3, etc.; πικρότερον ἑλλεβόρου AP 5.28 ( Cillactor).

children.label: II
children.definition: Ar. Fr. 320.6, Nicostr. 33, cf. Hsch.
band for binding corn-sheaves, in pl., Il. 18.553, h.Cer. 456, Hes. Sc. 291: sg., in Suid.

defect, deficiency, Hp. Praec. 9, Phld. D. 3.2 (pl.), etc.; τὰ καθʼ ὑμᾶς ἐλλείμματα shortcomings dependent on yourselves, D. 2.27; arrears, Id. 22.44; τοῦ γεγραμμένου νόμου ἔ. Arist. Rh. 1374a26; τὰ περὶ τὴν διάλεκτον ἐ. D.H. Dem. 20.
remnant, v.l. in LXX 2 Ki. 21.2.

definition: ἔλλειν ἴλλειν, κατέχειν, Hsch.:— Pass., ἐλλόμενα· περικλειόμενα, Id.; cf. εἴλω.

children.definition: incompletely, Plot. 1.3.6; opp. σφοδρῶς, Hsch. s.v. ἀκραῆ.
elliptic, defective, σχῆμα Eust. 66.24, cf. A.D. Conj. 226.20: c.gen., τῶν μορίων Id. Synt. 141.14. Adv. -κῶς Phlp. in APr. 316.30, Eust. 1080.17.

children.label: b
children.definition: summary, brief, Gal. 15.796. Adv. -κῶς Id. 18(1).881.
leave in, μόνον . . ἐλλελειμμένον left in a race, S. El. 736; leave behind, οὐδʼ ἐλλέλοιπας ἐλπίδα E. El. 609; τοῖόν σφιν ἐνέλλιπε θέλκτρον ἀοιδῆς A.R. 1.515.

leave out, leave undone, freq. with neg. Pron. neut., μηδὲν ἐ. ὅσων χρὴ πονεῖν S. Aj. 1379; οὐδὲν ἐλλείψουσι . . χειρουργίας Ar. Lys. 673; λέγε μηδὲν ἐλλείπων Pl. Plt. 269c, cf. Ti. 17b, X. Mem. 4.3.17; ἐ. τι τῶν νομίμων Id. Cyr. 1.2.14; τοῦτʼ αὐτὸ ἐ. Pl. Plt. 267c, cf. R. 362d; ἔνια, σμικρά, Id. Cra. 431c, 431d, etc.:— Pass., Id. Phlb. 18d; τῆς προθυμίας οὐδὲν ἐλλέλειπται Lys. 12.99; εὑρήσει οὐδὲν ἐλλειφθέν D. 18.303.

children.label: b
children.definition: fail to pay, leave unpaid, ἐλλελοιπότες εἰσφοράν Id. 24.172, cf. Arist. Ath. 48.1; τινὰ τῶν ὀψωνίων τοῖς μισθοφόροις Plb. 4.60.2.

fall short, fail, οὐ μὴν Τρίοπός γʼ ἐνέλειπεν h.Ap. 213; ἄτας οὐδὲν ἐλλείπει S. Ant. 584 (lyr.); ἤνπερ μὴ ʼλλίπωσιν αἱ δίκαι Ar. Pl. 859; ἐ. ἐν τῷ ἔργῳ Th. 1.120; τοῖς ἱππικοῖς Plb. 15.3.5; opp. περιγίγνεσθαι, Pl. Lg. 740d; opp. πλεονάζειν, Isoc. 2.33; opp. ὑπερβάλλειν, Pl. Lg. 719d, Arist. EN 1108b18; fail in duty, X. HG 7.5.8, Eq. 8.5; τὸ ἐλλεῖπον [τῆς ἐπιστήμης] a deficiency of . ., Th. 6.69; τὸ ἐ. ἐκπληρώσατε X. Cyr. 4.5.39, etc.; to be too small, Id. Cyn. 5.26; ἐλλείπων, ὁ, name of a throw of the dice, Eub. 57.4.

children.label: b
children.definition: fall short, χωρίῳ by an area, Pl. Men. 87a, cf. Euc. 6.27, al.

to be in want of, fall short of, lack, τὸν ἐλλείποντʼ ἔτι ἥβης ἀκμαίας A. Th. 10; ἐ. [χρημάτων] Th. 1.80; τῆς δόξης Id. 2.61; τὰ τῶν ἱκανῶν ἐλλείποντα X. Hier. 4.8; τὸ τίμημα ἐνέλιπε τῶν ἑξακισχιλίων διακοσίοις ταλάντοις fell short of the 6000 by 200, Plb. 2.62.7; τοσοῦτον ἐλλείπει τοῦ λυπεῖσθαι so far does he fall short of feeling pain, Arist. EN 1108b5; πολλοῦ γε καὶ τοῦ παντὸς ἐλλείπω (sc. τοῦ ταρβεῖν) A. Pr. 961: with a neg., προθυμίας γὰρ οὐδὲν ἐλλείπεις ib. 341, cf. Pl. Ti. 20c; οὔτε ἀνοίας οὐδὲν ἐλλείπει οὔτε ἀναισχυντίας Id. R. 571d: impers., ἐλλείπει πωμάτων there is lack of drink, Id. Lg. 844b; οἷς ἂν τῆς γενέσεως ἐλλείπῃ ib. 740c; ὧν δʼ ἐνέλειπε τῇ πόλει . . D. 18.302.

data.quote: οὔτε ἀνοίας οὐδὲν ἐλλείπει οὔτε ἀναισχυντίας

children.definition: to be inferior to, Pl. Alc. 1.122c; ἐμπειρίᾳ μηδὲν ἐκείνων ἐ. Id. R. 484d: also c. gen. rei, τἀνθάδε τῶν ἐκεῖ ἐ. Id. Alc. 1.122d.
μή c. inf., τί γὰρ ἐ. μὴ παραπαίειν; in what does it fall short of madness? A. Pr. 1056 (anap.); οὐδὲν ἐλλείψω τὸ μὴ . . πυθέσθαι S. Tr. 90.
part., ὅτι ἄν τις ἐλλείπῃ λέγων Pl. Phdr. 272b; οὐκ ἐλλείψει εὐχαριστῶν will not fail to give thanks, Decr. ap. D. 18.92: abs., οἱ ἐλλείποντες defaulters, Id. 22.44.
to be wanting or lacking to . ., c.dat., X. Mem. 2.1.8.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἐλλείπει τινά τι something fails one, Plb. 9.41.11; ἵνα μηδὲν αὐτὰς ἐλλείπῃ τῶν ἐπιτηδείων Id. 10.18.11.

data.quote: ἵνα μηδὲν αὐτὰς ἐλλείπῃ τῶν ἐπιτηδείων

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., to be surpassed, ἐλλείπεσθαι εὖ ποιῶν X. Mem. 2.6.5.
to be wanting, fail, Id. Cyr. 6.2.37, Eq. 3.8, etc.; to be inferior, Pl. R. 484d: c. gen., τινὸς εἰς σύνεσιν Id. Amat. 136a.
lick in, take oneʼs fill of, τινός Com.Adesp. 125 Meineke.
falling short, defect, opp. ὑπερβολή, Democr. 102, Pl. Prt. 356a; opp. ὑπεροχή, Arist. Ph. 187a17, Metaph. 1042b25; ὑπερβολὴ καὶ ἔ. καὶ τὸ μέσον Id. EN 1106b17.

data.quote: ὑπερβολὴ καὶ ἔ. καὶ τὸ μέσον

children.definition: the conic section ellipse, Apollon.Perg. Con. 1.13 (so called because the square on the ordinate is equal to a rectangle with height equal to the abscissa and applied to the parameter, but falling short of it).
ἐν ἐλλείψεσιν ἐνυπάρχειν to be present in deficiency, of the negative terms in an algebraical expression, Dioph. 1 Praef. p.14 T.
ellipse, Ath. 14.644a, A.D. Synt. 117.19; omission of a letter, Id. Pron. 56.28.
Olymp. in Mete. 67.37 (s.v.l.).
two, Theol.Ar. 10.

definition: ἔλλερος, dialectic for κακός, Call. Fr. 434, cf. Eust. 635.5, Hsch.

children.definition: talked of in the λέσχαι, commonly talked of, Hdt. 1.153.

definition: ἔλλετε, = ἔρρετε, Call. Fr. 292; cf. ἔλλατε (v. ἔλλαθι).

children.definition: albatus, Gloss.
come to an end in, PLond. 1.98r31.
Hsch. (dub.).

definition: Ἕλλην, ηνος, ὁ, Hellen, son of Deucalion, Hes. Fr. 7.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἕλληνες, οἱ, the Thessalian tribe of which Hellen was the reputed chief, Il. 2.684.
Greeks, Epigr. ap. Paus. 10.7.6, Hdt. 1.56, Th. 1.3, etc.; cf. Πανέλληνες.
Gentiles, whether heathens or Christians, opp. Jews, LXX Is. 9.12, Ev.Jo. 7.35, etc.
non-Egyptian (incl. Persians, etc.), PTeb. 5.169 (ii B.C.).
pagan, Jul. Ep. 114, Eun. VS p.524B., Dam. Isid. 204, Cod.Just. 1.11.10.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adj., = Ἑλληνικός, στρατός Pi. N. 10.25, etc.: with fem. Subst., Ἕλληνʼ ἐπίσταμαι φάτιν A. Ag. 1254; στολήν γʼ Ἕλληνα E. Heracl. 130; Ἕ. γυνή Philem. 55; Ἕ. ἀληθῶς οὖσα, of fortune, Apollod.Car. 5.10; Πυλῶν Ἑλλήνων D. 18.304: with neut. Subst., ἐν χωρίῳ Ἕλληνι Them. Or. 27.332d.

children.label: IV
children.definition: those who spoke or wrote Hellenistic Greek, opp. Ἀττικοί, ἄρτι· οἱ μὲν Ἀ. τὸ πρὸ ὀλίγου, οἱ δὲ Ἕ. καὶ ἐπὶ τοῦ νῦν λέγουσι Moer. 68, al., cf. POxy. 1012 Fr. 16; opp. οἱ παλαιοί, Moer. 145.

data.quote: Ἀττικοί, ἄρτι· οἱ μὲν Ἀ. τὸ πρὸ ὀλίγου, οἱ δὲ Ἕ. καὶ ἐπὶ τοῦ νῦν λέγουσι

children.definition: chief of the Greek community, title at Tanais, IPE 2.423, al.

definition: ἑλληνίζω, impf. ἑλλήνιζον without augm., Charito 4.5 codd.: aor. Act. ἑλληνίσαι D.C. 55.3: aor. Pass. without augm., Th. 2.68 codd.: pf. Pass. ἡλλήνισται J. AJ 1.6.1:—

children.definition: speak Greek, Ἕλλην μέν ἐστι καὶ ἑλληνίζει Pl. Men. 82b, cf. Chrm. 159a, Prt. 328a, etc.; ἑ. τῇ φωνῇ, τὴν φωνήν, Aeschin. 3.172, Charito l.c.; esp. speak or write pure or correct Greek, Arist. Rh. 1407a19, D.H. Pomp. 2.5; ἄκρως ἑ. S.E. M. 1.186; opp. βαρβαρίζω, ib. 246.

children.label: b
children.definition: οὐδὲ γὰρ ἂν ἑλληνίζοι οὕτως τὸ ἐρώτημα λεχθέν would not be Greek, Arist. SE 182a34.

children.label: c
children.definition: speak common Greek, opp. the Attic dialect, σὺ μὲν ἀττικίζεις . . οἱ δʼ Ἕλληνες ἑλληνίζομεν Posidipp. 28.

data.quote: σὺ μὲν ἀττικίζεις . . οἱ δʼ Ἕλληνες ἑλληνίζομεν

children.label: II
children.definition: make Greek, Hellenize, τὴν βάρβαρον Lib. Or. 11.103; translate into Greek, D.C. l.c.:— Pass., ἑλληνισθῆναι τὴν γλῶσσαν ἀπό τινος acquire the Greek language from . ., Th. l.c.; τὰ ὀνόματα . . ἡλλήνισται have assumed an Hellenic form, J. AJ 1.6.1.
Hellenic, Greek, Hdt. 4.108, etc.
ἑλληνική (sc. γλῶσσα), ἡ, the Greek language, Apoc. 9.11.
τὸ Ἑ. the Greeks collectively, Hdt. 7.139, al.; Greek soldiery, X. An. 1.4.13.

children.label: b
children.definition: Greek culture, D.H. 1.89: pl., Hdt. 4.78.
τὰ Ἑ. the history of Greek affairs, Th. 1.97, etc.; title of works by X., Theopomp.Hist., etc.; Greek literature, App. BC 4.67.

children.label: II
children.definition: like the Greeks, οὐ . . πατρῷον τόνδʼ ἐδεξάμην νόμον, οὐδʼ Ἑ. E. Alc. 684, cf. Ar. Ach. 115, Plu. Luc. 41: Comp. -ώτερος Id. Comp.Lyc.Num. 1; ἡ συγγνώμη τῆς τιμωρίας -ώτερον Lib. Ep. 75.4: Sup. -ώτατος D. 19.308, D.H. 1.89. Adv. -κῶς in Greek fashion, Hdt. 4.108, E. IT 660, Antiph. 184.

children.label: III
children.definition: pure Greek, οὐχ Ἑ. λέξις Orus ap. Eust. 859.55, cf. Ael.Dion. Fr. 207, S.E. M. 1.187. Adv. -κῶς in pure Greek, opp. βαρβαρικῶς, Phld. Lib. p.13 O., cf. S.E. M. 1.243, Porph. Abst. 3.3.
in Hellenistic Greek, opp. Ἀττικῶς, Moer. 1, al.; but also, opp. κοινόν ‘in common speech’, Id. 347, al.

children.label: IV
children.definition: pagan, LXX 2 Ma. 4.10, al., Jul. Ep. 84a, Suid. s.v. Διοκλητιανός.

definition: Ἑλλήνιος, Dor. Ἑλλάνιος [ᾱ] (also in Ar. Eq. 1253), α, ον, = foreg., Ζεὺς Ἑ., Ἀθανᾶ Ἑ., Rhetra ap. Plu. Lyc. 6 ( Συλλ- codd.); Ζεὺς Ἑ. Hdt. 9.7.αʹ, cf. Pi. N. 5.10, IG 12(5).910 ( Tenos), etc.; Ἀθηνᾶ Ἑ. E. Hipp. 1121 (lyr.); θεοὶ οἱ Ἑ. Hdt. 5.49, 92. ή, Luc. Herc. 2 codd., Hld. 2.23.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑλλήνιον, τό, Greek factory (with temples of Θεοὶ Ἑλλήνιοι) at Naucratis, Hdt. 2.178; also of buildings at Arsinoe and Memphis, BGU 133.6 (ii A.D.), Wilcken Chr. 221 (iii B.C.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Ἑλλανία, ἡ, = Ἑλλάς, E. Hel. 1147 (lyr.), etc.
Ἑλλήνιος, Pi. P. 11.50; ἀρεταὶ ἀέθλων Id. Pae. 4.23, cf. Cratin. 293, Lys. 30.18, Th. 1.35, D. 18.304, etc.; Ἑ. διάλεκτος, γλῶττα, Phld. D. 3.14.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑλληνίς (sc. γυνή), ἡ, Grecian woman, E. El. 1076, Men. 79.
pagan woman, Jul. Ep. 112.
imitation of the Greeks, Hellenism, LXX 2 Ma. 4.13.

children.label: II
children.definition: use of a pure Greek style and idiom, as an ἀρετὴ λόγου, Diog.Bab.Stoic. 3.214, cf. Phld. Po. 2.18, A.D. Pron. 71.25, S.E. M. 1.98; ἔνιοι λέγουσιν Ἑ. εἶναι τὸν ποιητήν (i.e. Homer), Lex.Vind. 311; περὶ Ἑλληνισμοῦ, title of works by Seleucus, Ath. 9.367a; by Ptolemy of Ascalon, Philoxenus and Tryphon, Suid.; κανόνες Ἑλληνισμοῦ, title of work by Irenaeus, Id.
use of the κοινή, opp. to strict Atticism, POxy. 1012 Fr. 17.

children.label: III
children.definition: paganism, Jul. Ep. 84a; ἡ τοῦ Ἑ. δυσσέβεια Cod.Just. 1.11.9.1.
one who uses the Greek language: a Greek Jew, Act. Ap. 6.1, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: gentile, heathen, Jul. Ep. 84a.
in the Greek language, Pl. Ti. 21e, PTaur. 1v4 (ii B.C.), Ph. 2.546, J. AJ 14.10.2, etc.; Ἑ. συνιέναι to understand Greek, X. An. 7.6.8; Ἑ. γινώσκεις; Act.Ap. 21.37; in Greek fashion, Luc. Scyth. 3.
flatter the Greeks, Plb. 25.3.1; affect Greek fashions, Id. 20.10.7.
Greeks resident at Memphis, PSI 5.531.6 (iii B.C.).
